{"uri": "8252734569", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:31:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:31:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:31:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.defensenews.com/industry/2024/07/31/boeing-names-aerospace-veteran-kelly-ortberg-as-new-ceo/", "title": "Boeing names aerospace veteran Kelly Ortberg as new CEO", "body": "Boeing named a longtime aerospace industry veteran on Wednesday as its next chief executive, who will take over a company that has been rocked by legal, regulatory and production problems.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, a former CEO at Boeing supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun as CEO and president effective Aug. 8, the company said. Calhoun announced in March that he would retire at the end of the year, and analysts generally praised the quicker transition.\n\nBoeing named its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty this month to a federal fraud charge in connection with its 737 Max jetliner and two crashes that killed 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration increased its oversight of the company after the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet raised manufacturing quality concerns.\n\nBoeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\" Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies, Mollenkopf said.\n\nThe company waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg, a spokesperson said. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nOrtberg emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial airplanes division.\n\nOrtberg led Rockwell Collins from 2013 to 2018, when it merged with United Technologies and wound up as part of RTX, the company formerly known as Raytheon. He retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nRichard Aboulafia, a longtime aerospace analyst and consultant and recently a harsh critic of the company, said the hire is great news for Boeing.\n\n\"He is a deeply respected leader in the aerospace industry, and brings more hope for a better future than the company has enjoyed in decades,\" Aboulafia said.\n\nDeutsche Bank analyst Scott Deuschle said Ortberg \"has an engineering background, experience in the aviation industry, and experience as a public company CEO.\"\n\nIn a statement issued by Boeing, Ortberg said, \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nCalhoun will serve as a special adviser to the Boeing board until next March.\n\nLike Calhoun, who took over as CEO in the wake of the two Max crashes, Ortberg will inherit the leadership of a company facing ongoing crises and criticism from inside and outside the company. Boeing has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety. It is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It faces a threatened strike this fall by its largest union, the International Association of Machinists.\n\nThe company is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nThe quarterly earnings reported Wednesday reflect the continuing challenges at Boeing. The company reported a loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier.\n\nExcluding special items, the loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion.\n\nThe commercial-airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA has limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners since shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year-end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine that it would pay as part of an agreement with the Justice Department to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the deal, which is opposed by many families of those who died in the two Max crashes.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. The smaller services business earned $870 million.", "source": {"uri": "defensenews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Defense News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Calhoun announced in March that he would retire at the end of the year, and analysts generally praised the quicker transition.\n\nBoeing named its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nOrtberg emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial airplanes division.\n\nOrtberg led Rockwell Collins from 2013 to 2018, when it merged with United Technologies and wound up as part of RTX, the company formerly known as Raytheon. He retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nRichard Aboulafia, a longtime aerospace analyst and consultant and recently a harsh critic of the company, said the hire is great news for Boeing.\n\n\"He is a deeply respected leader in the aerospace industry, and brings more hope for a better future than the company has enjoyed in decades,\" Aboulafia said.\n\nDeutsche Bank analyst Scott Deuschle said Ortberg \"has an engineering background, experience in the aviation industry, and experience as a public company CEO.\"\n\nIn a statement issued by Boeing, Ortberg said, \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nCalhoun will serve as a special adviser to the Boeing board until next March.\n\nLike Calhoun, who took over as CEO in the wake of the two Max crashes, Ortberg will inherit the leadership of a company facing ongoing crises and criticism from inside and outside the company. Boeing has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety. It is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It faces a threatened strike this fall by its largest union, the International Association of Machinists.\n\nThe company is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nThe quarterly earnings reported Wednesday reflect the continuing challenges at Boeing. The company reported a loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier.\n\nExcluding special items, the loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion.\n\nThe commercial-airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA has limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners since shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine that it would pay as part of an agreement with the Justice Department to plead guilty to fraud in connection with development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the deal, which is opposed by many families of those who died in the two Max crashes.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. {"uri": "8252686139", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:59:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:59:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:59:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.design-engineering.com/boeing-names-new-ceo-posts-1-4b-loss-1004043383/", "title": "Boeing names new CEO, posts $1.4B loss - Design Engineering", "body": "Robert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, a former CEO at Boeing supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun as CEO and president effective Aug. 8, the company said. Calhoun announced in March that he would retire at the end of the year, and analysts generally praised the quicker transition.\n\nBoeing named its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter.\n\nThe loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty this month to a federal fraud charge in connection with its 737 Max jetliner and two crashes that killed 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration increased its oversight of the company after the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet raised manufacturing quality concerns.\n\nBoeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\" Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies, Mollenkopf said.\n\nThe company waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg, a spokesperson said. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nOrtberg emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial airplanes division.\n\nOrtberg led Rockwell Collins from 2013 to 2018, when it merged with United Technologies and wound up as part of RTX, the company formerly known as Raytheon. He retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nRichard Aboulafia, a longtime aerospace analyst and consultant and recently a harsh critic of the company, said the hire is great news for Boeing.\n\n\"He is a deeply respected leader in the aerospace industry, and brings more hope for a better future than the company has enjoyed in decades,\" Aboulafia said.\n\nDeutsche Bank analyst Scott Deuschle said Ortberg \"has an engineering background, experience in the aviation industry, and experience as a public company CEO.\"\n\nIn a statement issued by Boeing, Ortberg said, \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nCalhoun will serve as a special adviser to the Boeing board until next March.\n\nLike Calhoun, who took over as CEO in the wake of the two Max crashes, Ortberg will inherit the leadership of a company facing ongoing crises and criticism from inside and outside the company. Boeing has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety. It is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It faces a threatened strike this fall by its largest union, the International Association of Machinists.\n\nThe company is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nThe quarterly earnings reported Wednesday reflect the continuing challenges at Boeing. The company reported a loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier.\n\nExcluding special items, the loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15 per cent, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion.\n\nThe commercial-airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million and revenue plunged 32 per cent as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.The FAA has limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners since shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine that it would pay as part of an agreement with the Justice Department to plead guilty to fraud in connection with development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the deal, which is opposed by many families of those who died in the two Max crashes.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. The smaller services business earned $870 million.", "source": {"uri": "design-engineering.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Design Engineering"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Financial_Services/Leasing_Services", "label": "dmoz/Business/Financial Services/Leasing Services", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://www.design-engineering.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/Unknown-14-1024x683.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9771357", "eventUri": "eng-9771357", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-08", "textStart": 132, "textEnd": 138}], "sentiment": -0.09019607843137256, "wgt": 225, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8252750013", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:42:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:42:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:41:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.pipestoneflyer.ca/business/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-loss-of-more-than-14-billion-in-second-quarter-7464557", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts loss of more than $1.4 billion in second quarter", "body": "Boeing named a longtime aerospace industry veteran Wednesday as its next chief executive, who will take over a company rocked by legal, regulatory and production problems and mounting financial repercussions.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, a former CEO at Boeing supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun as CEO and president effective Aug. 8, the company said. Calhoun said in March that he would retire at the end of the year, and analysts generally praised the quicker transition.\n\nBoeing announced its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and the company's revenue was lower than Wall Street's dismal expectations, as both Boeing's commercial airplanes business and defence unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing, which is the subject of multiple investigations into its safety culture and manufacturing quality.\n\nThe American aerospace giant agreed to plead guilty this month to a federal fraud charge in connection with its 737 Max jetliner and two crashes that killed 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration increased its oversight of the company and limited the number of planes it could produce after a panel blew off an Alaska Airlines Max flying at an altitude of 16,000 feet. No one was seriously hurt, but the frightening incident and subsequent scrutiny have damaged Boeing's reputation.\n\nBoeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\" Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies, Mollenkopf said.\n\nThe company waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg, a spokesperson said. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nOrtberg emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial airplanes division.\n\nOrtberg led Rockwell Collins from 2013 to 2018 when it merged with United Technologies and wound up as part of RTX, the company formerly known as Raytheon. He retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nRichard Aboulafia, a longtime aerospace analyst and consultant and recently a harsh critic of the company, said the hire is great news for Boeing.\n\n\"He is a deeply respected leader in the aerospace industry, and brings more hope for a better future than the company has enjoyed in decades,\" Aboulafia said.\n\nDeutsche Bank analyst Scott Deuschle said Ortberg \"has an engineering background, experience in the aviation industry, and experience as a public company CEO.\"\n\nIn a statement issued by Boeing, Ortberg said, \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nCalhoun will serve as a special adviser to the Boeing board until next March.\n\nLike Calhoun, who took over as CEO in the wake of the two Max crashes, Ortberg inherits the leadership of a company facing ongoing crises and criticism from inside and outside the company.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety. It is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It faces a threatened strike this fall by its largest union, the International Association of Machinists.\n\nThe company is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nThe quarterly earnings reported Wednesday reflected the continuing challenges at Boeing. The reported loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier. Since the start of 2019, Boeing has lost more than $25 billion.\n\nExcluding special items, the second-quarter loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion. The commercial airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million, and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year-end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine it agreed to pay as part of its plea deal with the Justice Department in connection with the development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the agreement, which also calls for the appointment of an independent compliance monitor and for Boeing to invest at least $455 million \"in its compliance, quality, and safety programs.\"\n\nMany families of the people who died in the two Max crashes, which took place off the coast of Indonesia in 2018 and in Ethiopia less than five months later, oppose the deal and plan to ask the judge to reject it.\n\nBoeing's defence and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. The smaller services business earned $870 million.\n\nBoeing shares rose 2% in morning trading.\n\nDavid Koenig, The Associated Press", "source": {"uri": "pipestoneflyer.ca", "dataType": "news", Calhoun announced in March that he would retire at the end of the year, and analysts generally praised the quicker transition.\n\nBoeing named its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty this month to a federal fraud charge in connection with its 737 Max jetliner and two crashes that killed 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration increased its oversight of the company after the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet raised manufacturing quality concerns.\n\nBoeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\" Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies, Mollenkopf said.\n\nThe company waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg, a spokesperson said. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nOrtberg emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial airplanes division.\n\nOrtberg led Rockwell Collins from 2013 to 2018, when it merged with United Technologies and wound up as part of RTX, the company formerly known as Raytheon. He retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nRichard Aboulafia, a longtime aerospace analyst and consultant and recently a harsh critic of the company, said the hire is great news for Boeing.\n\n\"He is a deeply respected leader in the aerospace industry, and brings more hope for a better future than the company has enjoyed in decades,\" Aboulafia said.\n\nDeutsche Bank analyst Scott Deuschle said Ortberg \"has an engineering background, experience in the aviation industry, and experience as a public company CEO.\"\n\nIn a statement issued by Boeing, Ortberg said, \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nCalhoun will serve as a special adviser to the Boeing board until next March.\n\nLike Calhoun, who took over as CEO in the wake of the two Max crashes, Ortberg will inherit the leadership of a company facing ongoing crises and criticism from inside and outside the company. Boeing has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety. It is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It faces a threatened strike this fall by its largest union, the International Association of Machinists.\n\nThe company is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nThe quarterly earnings reported Wednesday reflect the continuing challenges at Boeing. Calhoun announced in March that he would retire at the end of the year, and analysts generally praised the quicker transition.\n\nBoeing named its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. {"uri": "8252679630", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:57:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:57:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:55:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-loss-of-more-than-1-4-billion-in/article_34fe275e-6121-5d31-ba5d-884418006e14.html", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts loss of more than $1.4 billion in second quarter", "body": "By DAVID KOENIG - AP Airlines Writer\n\nBoeing named a longtime aerospace industry veteran on Wednesday as its next chief executive, who will take over a company that has been rocked by legal, regulatory and production problems.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, a former CEO at Boeing supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun as CEO and president effective Aug. 8, the company said. The loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty this month to a federal fraud charge in connection with its 737 Max jetliner and two crashes that killed 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration increased its oversight of the company after the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet raised manufacturing quality concerns.\n\nBoeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\" Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies, Mollenkopf said.\n\nThe company waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg, a spokesperson said. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nOrtberg emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial airplanes division.\n\nOrtberg led Rockwell Collins from 2013 to 2018, when it merged with United Technologies and wound up as part of RTX, the company formerly known as Raytheon. He retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nRichard Aboulafia, a longtime aerospace analyst and consultant and recently a harsh critic of the company, said the hire is great news for Boeing.\n\n\"He is a deeply respected leader in the aerospace industry, and brings more hope for a better future than the company has enjoyed in decades,\" Aboulafia said.\n\nDeutsche Bank analyst Scott Deuschle said Ortberg \"has an engineering background, experience in the aviation industry, and experience as a public company CEO.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIn a statement issued by Boeing, Ortberg said, \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nCalhoun will serve as a special adviser to the Boeing board until next March.\n\nLike Calhoun, who took over as CEO in the wake of the two Max crashes, Ortberg will inherit the leadership of a company facing ongoing crises and criticism from inside and outside the company. Boeing has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety. It is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It faces a threatened strike this fall by its largest union, the International Association of Machinists.\n\nThe company is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nThe quarterly earnings reported Wednesday reflect the continuing challenges at Boeing. The company reported a loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier.\n\nExcluding special items, the loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion.\n\nThe commercial-airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA has limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners since shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine that it would pay as part of an agreement with the Justice Department to plead guilty to fraud in connection with development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the deal, which is opposed by many families of those who died in the two Max crashes.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. The smaller services business earned $870 million.\n\nBoeing shares rose 2% in morning trading.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8252659968", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:42:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:42:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:41:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.local3news.com/regional-national/boeing-names-new-ceo-after-losses-more-than-triple/article_dd98f852-4f49-11ef-825c-fb90be36b328.html", "title": "Boeing names new CEO after losses more than triple", "body": "Boeing named a new CEO Wednesday after reporting a core operating loss of $1.4 billion in the second quarter -- more than triple the loss from a year ago -- as increased scrutiny of the safety and quality of its planes kept the troubled company from making enough aircraft to return to profitability.\n\nBoeing announced Robert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, former CEO of supplier Rockwell Collins, will be its new CEO, effective August 8, replacing retiring Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun, who has been under fire for the company's problems.\n\n\"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" said Ortberg in a statement from the company. \"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront.\"\n\nOrtberg, who noted \"there is much work to be done\" at Boeing, has a background that could be encouraging to some staff who have criticized Boeing's management for having too much of a emphasis on finance rather than the engineering quality. Ortberg earned his college degree in mechanical engineering.\n\nBut Ortberg's appointment doesn't necessarily guarantee the right decisions will be made by the company's new leadership. While Calhoun's background is in finance, his predecessor, Dennis Muilenburg, who was CEO at Boeing at the time of the development of the troubled 737 Max jet and the two fatal crashes of the plane that led to its 20-month grounding and five years of financial losses, also had an engineering background.\n\nOrtberg started work in the aviation industry in 1983 as an engineer at Texas Instruments, and then joined Rockwell Collins in 1987 as a program manager. He became CEO of Rockwell Collins in 2013, and retired from the company in 2021.\n\n\"Kelly is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies,\" said Boeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf in a statement. \"We look forward to working with him as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in its long history.\"\n\nRockwell Collins provides avionics, the electrical systems used on aircraft, and information technology used in the aerospace industry. It was purchased by United Technologies in 2018 and now operates as Collins Aerospace. Ortberg stayed with the company for three years as it was integrated into United Technologies, and then he retired.\n\nEven one of Boeing's harshest critics found hope in the appointment of Ortberg.\n\n\"The arrival of a new CEO at Boeing could not have happened at a more crucial and necessary time for the safety of the traveling public around the world,\" said Robert Clifford, attorney for the families of 737 Max crash victims. He said that under Muilenberg, Calhoun, and Boeing's \"do nothing\" board, the company has been in a \"nosedive.\"\n\nSerious problems to solve\n\nOrtberg will have his hands full fixing the problems at Boeing, which has not posted a profitable year since 2019. Since then, its core operating losses totaled $33.3 billion, including the loss announced Wednesday. That loss was far larger than forecast by analysts. Boeing will have difficulty returning to profitability until it can convince regulators that it has fixed problems with the safety and quality of its jets.\n\nThe company has admitted that two 737 Max crashes in October 2018 and March 2019 that killed a total of 346 people were the result of a design flaw. The crashes and the time it took to fix the design cost the company more than $20 billion.\n\nIt recently agreed to plead guilty to charges that its employees defrauded the Federal Aviation Administration during the original certification process for the 737 Max. As part of the guilty plea, Boeing agreed to operate under the supervision of a court-appointed monitor.\n\nThe company has come under renewed scrutiny after a 737 Max plane's door plug blew off shortly after takeoff in January. More than a dozen whistleblowers have told Congressional investigators about bad practices at Boeing, including the use of parts that did not meet standards. Many said Boeing retaliated against employees who complained about safety practices.\n\nThe company has agreed to an FAA demand to curb production of the 737 Max until the regulator is satisfied it has fixed its safety and quality issues. But that will keep the losses building at Boeing as it can't make money at its current level of production.\n\nBoeing's problems go beyond the 737 Max issues. The company also has problems with its defense business, which resulted in $913 million in losses on its defense, space and security unit, nearly double the $527 million it lost there a year earlier.\n\nIts Starliner space ship made its first crewed flight in the quarter but developed problems after docking at the International Space Station, leaving its two astronauts stuck at the ISS with no date yet known for their return.\n\nBoeing also reported it had additional losses in its program to deliver two new 747 jets that will be used as the new Air Force One planes by the president. That contract has already cost Boeing more than $2 billion going into the quarter. It said Wednesday that increased engineering costs for that contract and for the Starliner contributed to Boeing's increased losses.\n\nShares of Boeing (BA) initially fell in premarket trading on the financial results, then bounced back on news moments later that Ortberg had been tapped as CEO. Shares were up more than 1% at the US market open. But shares are down 28% year to date through Tuesday's market close.\n\nThis story was updated with additional reporting and context.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. Rick Larsen, who represents Washington's 2nd congressional district, said in a statement Wednesday morning that Ortberg \"has his work cut out for him.\"\n\n\"I look forward to meeting Mr. Ortberg soon, but that is not as important as focusing on Boeing returning to the top of its game,\" Larsen said. (Read the full statement at the bottom of this story.)\n\nOrtberg will also serve on Boeing's Board of Directors.\n\nEarlier this year, Calhoun announced he would retire from the company. He served as president and CEO since January 2020, and was a member of Boeing's Board of Directors since 2009.\n\n\"The Board conducted a thorough and extensive search process over the last several months to select the next CEO of Boeing and Kelly has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter,\" said Steven Mollenkopf, Chair of the Board. \"Kelly is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies. We look forward to working with him as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in its long history.\"\n\nShares rose more than 2% before the opening bell Wednesday.\n\nBoeing's loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected. Revenue fell 15% from a year earlier, and both its commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the Max, two of which crashed, killing 346 people. It is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety.\n\nThe company is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. Rick Larsen (D-Everett) released a statement on Boeing's new president & CEO Wednesday morning.\n\nLarsen is the lead Democrat on the Transportation & Infrastructure Committee:\n\n\"I am encouraged about the announcement of Kelly Ortberg as the new President and CEO of The Boeing Company. Mr. Ortberg is a mechanical engineer. I hope that means he will ensure that his top message for everyone is building the best airplane means building the safest airplane in the world.\n\n\"But Mr. Ortberg has his work cut out for him.\n\n\"First, he has to ensure a continued commitment to the safety and quality plan that is Boeing's pathway to earning the trust and confidence of the traveling public.\n\n\"Second, he needs to listen to the women and men of the Machinists Union in the current labor negotiations to ensure they are compensated for their work and treated well for carrying much of the burden for the company over the last several years.\n\n\"Finally, Boeing needs to complete the acquisition of Spirit AeroSystems, bringing back a key part of its supply chain into the company.\n\n\"I look forward to meeting Mr. Ortberg soon, but that is not as important as focusing on Boeing returning to the top of its game.\"", "source": {"uri": "finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! {"uri": "8252726771", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:26:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:26:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:26:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://richmond.com/news/state-regional/business/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-loss-of-more-than-1-4-billion-in/article_f7ea3ace-4f4c-11ef-94b5-9f5bb88e9227.html", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts loss of more than $1.4 billion in second quarter", "body": "DAVID KOENIG Associated Press\n\nArlington-based Boeing named a longtime aerospace industry veteran on Wednesday as its next chief executive, who will take over a company that has been rocked by legal, regulatory and production problems.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, a former CEO at Boeing supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun as CEO and president effective Aug. 8, the company said. Calhoun announced in March that he would retire at the end of the year, and analysts generally praised the quicker transition.\n\nBoeing named its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nPeople are also reading... Outer Banks wild stallion hit, killed on the beach 'Illegal' recruiting a hot topic at VHSL meeting in Abingdon; John Marshall called out Former Virginia EMS employee pleads guilty to embezzling $4 million As Kings Dominion merges with Six Flags, some fans worry quality will suffer Virginia collects $1.2 billion more revenue than expected Thousands watch Chincoteague wild ponies complete 99th swim UPDATE: Police ID victim, announce arrest in shooting involving Chesterfield couple Search for missing 12-year-old swimmer on Outer Banks ends in tragedy UVa's Gretchen Walsh sets Olympic record in 100 butterfly on opening night of Paris Games Youngkin names Scalia daughter to Board of Education Teel: Jeff Jones hosts special Virginia basketball reunion Dominion customers' bills to rise for offshore project costs Henrico homeowners upset by Goochland quarry expansion Kline's Dairy Bar opens in Chesterfield Richmonders weigh in on Kamala Harris as presumptive Democratic nominee\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty this month to a federal fraud charge in connection with its 737 Max jetliner and two crashes that killed 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration increased its oversight of the company after the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet raised manufacturing quality concerns.\n\nBoeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\" Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies, Mollenkopf said.\n\nThe company waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg, a spokesperson said. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nOrtberg emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial airplanes division.\n\nOrtberg led Rockwell Collins from 2013 to 2018, when it merged with United Technologies and wound up as part of RTX, the company formerly known as Raytheon. He retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nRichard Aboulafia, a longtime aerospace analyst and consultant and recently a harsh critic of the company, said the hire is great news for Boeing.\n\n\"He is a deeply respected leader in the aerospace industry, and brings more hope for a better future than the company has enjoyed in decades,\" Aboulafia said.\n\nDeutsche Bank analyst Scott Deuschle said Ortberg \"has an engineering background, experience in the aviation industry, and experience as a public company CEO.\"\n\nIn a statement issued by Boeing, Ortberg said, \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | Stitcher | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nCalhoun will serve as a special adviser to the Boeing board until next March.\n\nLike Calhoun, who took over as CEO in the wake of the two Max crashes, Ortberg will inherit the leadership of a company facing ongoing crises and criticism from inside and outside the company. Boeing has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019.\n\nBoeing is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety. It is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It faces a threatened strike this fall by its largest union, the International Association of Machinists.\n\nThe company is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nThe quarterly earnings reported Wednesday reflect the continuing challenges at Boeing. The company reported a loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier.\n\nExcluding special items, the loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion.\n\nThe commercial-airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA has limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners since shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine that it would pay as part of an agreement with the Justice Department to plead guilty to fraud in connection with development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the deal, which is opposed by many families of those who died in the two Max crashes.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. The smaller services business earned $870 million.\n\nBoeing shares rose 2% in morning trading.\n\nFrom the Archives: Photos of the Richmond region in the 1980s", "source": {"uri": "richmond.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Richmond Times-Dispatch"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Financial_Services/Leasing_Services", "label": "dmoz/Business/Financial Services/Leasing Services", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/richmond.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/7e/f7ea3ace-4f4c-11ef-94b5-9f5bb88e9227/66aa51894de5c.preview.jpg?crop=1024%2C538%2C0%2C72&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9771357", "eventUri": "eng-9771357", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-08", "textStart": 369, "textEnd": 375}], "sentiment": -0.1607843137254902, "wgt": 213, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8252666207", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:47:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:47:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:46:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/news/state-and-regional/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-loss-of-more-than-1-4-billion-in/article_b8c29189-e692-54a9-9aad-189aa4786528.html", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts loss of more than $1.4 billion in second quarter", "body": "By DAVID KOENIG - AP Airlines Writer\n\nBoeing named a longtime aerospace industry veteran on Wednesday as its next chief executive, who will take over a company that has been rocked by legal, regulatory and production problems.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, a former CEO at Boeing supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun as CEO and president effective Aug. 8, the company said. Calhoun announced in March that he would retire at the end of the year, and analysts generally praised the quicker transition.\n\nBoeing named its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nPeople are also reading... The Big Tri City Fair looks to bring fun and entertainment HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL: Hart steps down at Honaker, not seeing commitment in offseason OLYMPICS: Johnson City-born Brody Malone helps U.S. get bronze in men's gymnastics team competition PREP SPORTS: VHSL leaders hold public meeting in Abingdon Antiques showcased at Virginia Highlands Festival Badcock Furniture closing all its retail locations MLB: Evan Carter's back injury among Rangers concerns PRO GOLF: Runner-up for Connor Creasy (Abingdon) in PGA Americas Tour tourney in Ottawa HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Versatile Elliott to see plenty of the field for Vikings Drug probe leads to arrests, seizure of $1.9M of meth, fentanyl BHC SOFTBALL PLAYER OF YEAR: Muncy completes stellar career with state title at Rye Cove This theater season brings friendship, camaraderie and nostalgia to the stage Candidate Cao meets with Republicans in Abingdon Owens will be missed at annual Creeper Trail Ride to End Cancer Southwest Virginia economy resilient in face of population declines\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty this month to a federal fraud charge in connection with its 737 Max jetliner and two crashes that killed 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration increased its oversight of the company after the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet raised manufacturing quality concerns.\n\nBoeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\" Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies, Mollenkopf said.\n\nThe company waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg, a spokesperson said. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nOrtberg emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial airplanes division.\n\nOrtberg led Rockwell Collins from 2013 to 2018, when it merged with United Technologies and wound up as part of RTX, the company formerly known as Raytheon. He retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nRichard Aboulafia, a longtime aerospace analyst and consultant and recently a harsh critic of the company, said the hire is great news for Boeing.\n\n\"He is a deeply respected leader in the aerospace industry, and brings more hope for a better future than the company has enjoyed in decades,\" Aboulafia said.\n\nDeutsche Bank analyst Scott Deuschle said Ortberg \"has an engineering background, experience in the aviation industry, and experience as a public company CEO.\"\n\nIn a statement issued by Boeing, Ortberg said, \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nCalhoun will serve as a special adviser to the Boeing board until next March.\n\nLike Calhoun, who took over as CEO in the wake of the two Max crashes, Ortberg will inherit the leadership of a company facing ongoing crises and criticism from inside and outside the company. Boeing has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety. It is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It faces a threatened strike this fall by its largest union, the International Association of Machinists.\n\nThe company is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nThe quarterly earnings reported Wednesday reflect the continuing challenges at Boeing. The company reported a loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier.\n\nExcluding special items, the loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion.\n\nThe commercial-airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA has limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners since shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine that it would pay as part of an agreement with the Justice Department to plead guilty to fraud in connection with development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the deal, which is opposed by many families of those who died in the two Max crashes.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. The smaller services business earned $870 million.\n\nBoeing shares rose 2% in morning trading.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed without permission.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "heraldcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "HeraldCourier.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "david_koenig@heraldcourier.com", "name": "David Koenig", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Financial_Services/Leasing_Services", "label": "dmoz/Business/Financial Services/Leasing Services", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/heraldcourier.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/6a/96a578ed-8097-5d06-80eb-feb29050e48d/66aa282a24fc7.image.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9771357", "eventUri": "eng-9771357", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-08", "textStart": 360, "textEnd": 366}], "sentiment": 0.08235294117647052, "wgt": 212, "relevance": 1}

It is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety.\n\nThe company, based in Arlington, Virginia, also is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nThe quarterly earnings reported Wednesday reflect the significant challenges at Boeing. "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/gazette.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/b/5e/b5ea8530-b719-5333-9a59-f70e9ee44dc7/66aa40bdc6a53.image.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9771357", "eventUri": "eng-9771357", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-08", "textStart": 499, "textEnd": 505}], "sentiment": -0.1764705882352942, "wgt": 212, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8252539332", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:25:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:25:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:24:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://globalnews.ca/news/10662271/boeing-new-ceo-second-quarter-earnings-loss/", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts more than US$1.4B loss in 2nd quarter - National | Globalnews.ca", "body": "Boeing named a longtime aerospace industry veteran as its next chief executive, who will take over a company that has been rocked by legal, regulatory and production problems.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, 64, a former CEO at aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun, 67, as CEO effective Aug. 8, the company said on Wednesday.\n\nBoeing announced its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than US$1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the Max, two of which crashed, killing 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration has increased its oversight of the company following mistakes including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet. It is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety.\n\nThe company is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nOrtberg will become CEO and president on Aug. 8, Boeing said. He emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial-airplanes division.\n\nChairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\"\n\nMollenkopf said Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies.\n\nA Boeing spokesperson said the company had waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, reported a loss of US$1.44 billion for the second quarter, compared with a loss of US$149 million a year earlier.\n\nExcluding special items, the loss worked out to US$2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15 per cent, to US$16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion.\n\nThe commercial-airplanes division had an operating loss of US$715 million and revenue plunged 32 per cent as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA has limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners since shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of US$244 million to cover a fine that it would pay as part of an agreement with the Justice Department to plead guilty to fraud in connection with development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the deal, which is opposed by many families of those who died in the two Max crashes.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost US$913 million because of US$1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. The smaller services business earned $870 million.\n\nBoeing shares added two per cent in premarket trading.", "source": {"uri": "globalnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "Global News"}, {"uri": "2024-07-439615968", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:52:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:52:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:32:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/business/2024/07/31/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-a-loss-of-more-than-14-billion-in-second-quarter/", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts a loss of more than $1.4 billion in second quarter", "body": "Robert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, former CEO at aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun as CEO effective Aug. 8.\n\nBoeing named a longtime aerospace industry veteran as its next chief executive, who will take over a company that has been rocked by legal, regulatory and production problems.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, 64, a former CEO at aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun, 67, as CEO effective Aug. 8, the company said on Wednesday.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBoeing announced its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBusiness Briefing\n\nBecome a business insider with the latest news.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogle\n\nFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the Max, two of which crashed, killing 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration has increased its oversight of the company following mistakes including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet. It is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety.\n\nThe company is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nOrtberg will become CEO and president on Aug. 8, Boeing said. He emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial-airplanes division.\n\nChairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMollenkopf said Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA Boeing spokesperson said the company had waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, reported a loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier.\n\nExcluding special items, the loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nRevenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion.\n\nThe commercial-airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA has limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners since shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine that it would pay as part of an agreement with the Justice Department to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the deal, which is opposed by many families of those who died in the two Max crashes.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. The smaller services business earned $870 million.\n\nBoeing shares added 2% in premarket trading.\n\nRelated Stories\n\nView More\n\nAirline industry gets win after court stalls fee disclosure rule\n\nSouthwest Airlines is kicking off red-eye flights, but not at Dallas Love Field", "source": {"uri": "dallasnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Dallas Morning News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@dallasnews.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}], "concepts": [], "categories": [], "image": "https://dmn-dallas-news-prod.cdn.arcpublishing.com/resizer/v2/VDFTEOHC6FN5HEYMDD6YEV36RE.jpg?auth=54055d8446b75a2bbce0e09237bc72b7f85a59393f130cda7e890e88f331a2fe&height=467&width=830&smart=true&quality=40", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9771357", "eventUri": "eng-9771357", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-08", "textStart": 119, "textEnd": 125, "freq": 3}], "sentiment": -0.04313725490196074, "wgt": 211, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-439569475", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:12:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:12:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:59:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.denver7.com/business/company-news/boeing-names-new-president-and-ceo-following-big-second-quarter-loss", "title": "Boeing names new president and CEO following big second quarter loss", "body": "A Boeing ecoDemonstrator Explorer, a 787-10 Dreamliner, sits on the tarmac.\n\nBoeing has named a new president and CEO after reporting a loss of over $1.4 billion in the second quarter.\n\nEffective Aug. 8, Robert K. \"Kelly\" Ortberg will be on the job. He will also serve on Boeing's board of directors.\n\nOrtberg will succeed David Calhoun, who announced his intention to retire earlier this year. Calhoun has served as Boeing's president and CEO since January 2020 and has been a member of the company's board of directors since 2009.\n\nOrtberg, who was previously a president and CEO for Rockwell Collins, has over 35 years of aerospace leadership experience.\n\n\"The board conducted a thorough and extensive search process over the last several months to select the next CEO of Boeing and Kelly has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter,\" chair of the board Steven Mollenkopf said in a press release. \"Kelly is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies. We look forward to working with him as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in its long history.\"\n\nRELATED STORY | Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun to step down in wake of 737 Max crisis\n\nOrtberg also spoke out about his new venture.\n\n\"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" Ortberg said in a press release. \"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront. There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nOrtberg joins Boeing amid a slew of controversy for the company.\n\nIn recent years, Boeing has faced a myriad of issues with its planes, including deadly crashes and a door plug flying off a jet in mid-air with a plane full of passengers. the company has been the subject of recent investigations as its safety and protocols have been called into question.\n\nWith Ortberg's appointment, Boeing thanked Calhoun for his leadership.\n\n\"The board would also like to thank Dave Calhoun for his strong leadership at The loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the Max, two of which crashed, killing 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration has increased its oversight of the company following mistakes including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet. It is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety.\n\nThe company is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nOrtberg will become CEO and president on Aug. 8, Boeing said. He emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial-airplanes division.\n\nChairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\"\n\nMollenkopf said Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies.\n\nA Boeing spokesperson said the company had waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, reported a loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier.\n\nExcluding special items, the loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion.\n\nThe commercial-airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA has limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners since shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine that it would pay as part of an agreement with the Justice Department to plead guilty to fraud in connection with development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the deal, which is opposed by many families of those who died in the two Max crashes.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. {"uri": "8252439576", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:23:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:23:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:23:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.flightglobal.com/airframers/former-collins-chief-ortberg-to-succeed-calhoun-as-boeing-ceo/159430.article", "title": "Former Collins chief Ortberg to succeed Calhoun as Boeing CEO", "body": "Longtime aerospace executive and former Collins Aerospace chief Kelly Ortberg will succeed David Calhoun as Boeing's chief executive on 8 August.\n\nBoeing disclosed the change on 31 July, saying its board of directors elected Ortberg as the company's incoming leader. Ortberg will also serve on Boeing's board of directors.\n\n\"The board conducted a thorough and extensive search process over the last several months to select the next CEO of Boeing, and Kelly has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter,\" says Boeing board chair Steven Mollenkopf. \"Kelly is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies.\"\n\nThe news brings to a close much uncertainty over who would lead Boeing when current embattled CEO Calhoun steps down. Boeing disclosed earlier this year that Calhoun would retire before year-end, kicking off a search for a successor.\n\nThe company's board of directors had reportedly considered candidates including GE Aerospace CEO Larry Culp, Spirit AeroSystems CEO Patrick Shanahan, Boeing Commercial Airplanes CEO Stephanie Pope and Boeing director David Gitlin.\n\n\"I'm extremely honoured and humbled to join this iconic company,\" says Ortberg. \"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront.\"\n\nOrtberg began his career in 1983, taking an engineering job at Texas Instruments before joining Rockwell Collins in 1987 and rising to the position of Rockwell CEO in 2013. He was later CEO of Collins Aerospace, a company formed by United Technologies after it acquired Rockwell in 2018.\n\nOrtberg is now a board member of RTX, which owns Collins Aerospace.\n\nCalhoun became Boeing's CEO in 2020 during the 737 Max crisis, succeeding Dennis Muilenburg.\n\n\"The board would also like to thank Dave Calhoun for his strong leadership at Boeing, first as chair and then
