{"uri": "8252492353", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:57:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:57:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:56:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.euronews.com/business/2024/07/31/troubled-plane-maker-boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-reveals-billion-dollar-loss", "title": "Troubled Boeing names new CEO as it reveals billion-dollar loss", "body": "Boeing said in March that its current CEO David Calhoun would step down by the end of the year.\n\nA long-term industry executive is to take over as chief executive of the troubled aircraft manufacturer next week, Boeing has announced as it revealed a loss of more than $1.4 billion (\u20ac1.3 billion) in the second quarter of 2024.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, a 64-year-old former CEO at aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun as CEO, the company said.\n\nOrtberg, who only emerged recently as a leading candidate, will become CEO and president on 8 August, Boeing said.\n\nOthers who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial-planes division.\n\nChairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after \"a thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\"\n\nOrtberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies, Mollenkopf said.\n\nShares rose more than 2% before Wednesday's after the news was released.\n\nBoeing's loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected. Revenue fell 15% from a year earlier, and both its commercial-planes business and defence unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the Max, two of which crashed, killing 346 people.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration has increased its overseeing of the company following a number of problems, including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet.\n\nIt denies whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that cut back on safety.\n\nThe company is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor.\n\nIt is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner.\n\nIt is also facing a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Ortberg served as the head of Rockwell Collins from 2013 through its integration with United Technologies and RTX, until he retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nOrtberg's appointment will be effective as of August 8, Boeing said Wednesday in a statement. .\n\nThe appointment comes four months after Calhoun announced he would be stepping down as the CEO of Boeing following a mid-air blowout of a door panel on one of its Boeing 737 Max 9 planes, which spurred scrutiny from regulators and lawmakers. Calhoun had joined the company with the mandate to steady the business following two deadly crashes of Boeing aircraft in 2018 and 2019, to which Boeing earlier this month agreed to plead guilty to a criminal fraud charge.\n\nIn a statement, Ortberg said the company is facing \"much work to be done.\" He added he is committed to working with the company's 170,000 employees \"with safety and quality at the forefront.\"\n\nSeparately, Boeing reported that it lost more than $1.4 billion in the second quarter, a wider loss than expected by Wall Street. Revenue also fell short of expectations, dipping 15% from a year earlier.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The Federal Aviation Administration has increased its oversight of the company following mistakes including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet. It is is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety.\n\nThe company is also dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. {"uri": "8252467614", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:42:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:42:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:41:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/business/Boeing-names-new-CEO-after-losses-more-than-triple-1943252", "title": "Boeing names new CEO after losses more than triple", "body": "Boeing named a new CEO after it reported a core operating loss of $1.4 billion in the second quarter - more than triple the loss from a year ago - as increased scrutiny of the safety and quality of its planes kept the troubled company from making enough aircraft to return to profitability.\n\nBoeing announced Robert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, the former CEO of supplier Rockwell Collins, will be its new CEO, effective August 8, replacing retiring Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun, who has been under fire for the company's problems. Ortberg has a background as an engineer, not in finance, having earned his college degree in mechanical engineering.\n\n\"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" said Ortberg in a statement from the company. \"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront.\"\n\nOrtberg, who noted \"there is much work to be done\" at Boeing, has a background that could be encouraging to some staff who have criticized Boeing's management for having too much of a emphasis on finance rather than the engineering quality.\n\nBut Ortberg's appointment doesn't necessarily guarantee the right decisions will be made by the company's new leadership. While Calhoun's background is in finance, his predecessor, Dennis Muilenburg, the CEO of Boeing at the time of the development of the troubled 737 Max jet and the two fatal crashes of the plane that led to its 20-month grounding and five years of financial losses, also had an engineering background.\n\nOrtberg started work in the aviation industry in 1983 as an engineer at Texas Instruments, and then joined Rockwell Collins in 1987 as a program manager. He became CEO of Rockwell Collins in 2013, and retired from the company in 2021.\n\n\"Kelly is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies,\" said Boeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf in a statement. \"We look forward to working with him as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in its long history.\"\n\nRockwell Collins provides avionics, the electrical systems used on aircraft, and information technology used in the aerospace industry. It was purchased by United Technologies in 2018 and now operates as Collins Aerospace. Ortberg stayed with the company for three years as it was integrated into United Technologies, and then he retired.\n\nHe will have his hands full fixing the problems at Boeing, which has not posted a profitable year since 2019. Since then, its core operating losses totaled $33.3 billion, including the loss announced Wednesday.\n\nBoeing will have difficulty returning to profitability until it can convince regulators that it {"uri": "8252410660", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:07:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:07:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:06:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/business/boeing-appoints-kelly-ortberg-as-new-ceo/articleshow/112169485.cms", "title": "Boeing appoints Kelly Ortberg as new CEO and President", "body": "Boeing has appointed Kelly Ortberg as the new President and CEO, effective August 8, 2024, succeeding Dave Calhoun. Ortberg's primary challenge will be to turn around the company's financial woes, including a $1.4 billion loss and setbacks in its defense and space business. With over 35 years of aerospace experience, Ortberg is expected to lead Boeing through a pivotal period. The company aims to pivot from aggressive fixed-price contracts and manage its quality crisis to restore stability.Boeing has announced the appointment of Kelly Ortberg as its new President and CEO, effective August 8, 2024. Ortberg, a seasoned aerospace executive, will succeed Dave Calhoun, who has served as CEO since January 2020 and announced his retirement earlier this year. \"The Board conducted a thorough and extensive search process over the last several months to select the next CEO of Boeing, and Kelly has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter,\" said Steven Mollenkopf, Chair of Boeing's Board of Directors. Ortberg will also join Boeing's Board of Directors.\n\nThe leadership change comes at a crucial time for Boeing, which recently reported a $1.4 billion quarterly loss. The company's Defense, Space, and Security unit has significantly contributed to these losses due to cost overruns on fixed-price contracts. These contracts, which have high margins, have made Boeing vulnerable to inflationary pressures that have impacted U.S. corporate earnings in recent years. In 2023 and 2022 alone, the unit's losses amounted to billions of dollars.\n\nReuters reported that Boeing's commercial aircraft production has also faced considerable setbacks. In January, a cabin panel on a 737 MAX 9 jet blew off midair, leading to a production slowdown and intense regulatory scrutiny. The U.S. aviation regulator has capped the production of 737 MAX jets at 38 per month, but actual production has sometimes been lower. This has led to reduced deliveries and frustrated customers, with Boeing delivering 92 aircraft in the second quarter of this year, down 32% from the previous year.\n\nTo address these challenges, Boeing has announced a strategic pivot away from aggressive bidding on fixed-price contracts, which have proven financially risky. \"Ahead of last week's Farnborough Air Show, the unit's head had said it was 'significantly challenged' during the quarter,\" highlighting the need for a strategic shift. Boeing CFO Brian West stated in May that the company will \"burn rather than generate cash in 2024,\" due to lower jet deliveries compared to the previous year.\n\nOrtberg's Vision\n\nOrtberg, who brings over 35 years of aerospace experience, expressed his commitment to leading Boeing through these turbulent times. \"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" Ortberg said. \"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront. There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nOrtberg's extensive background includes key leadership roles at Rockwell Collins and its integration with United Technologies and RTX. He has served on various boards, including the Aerospace Industries Association (AIA) and Aptiv PLC. His experience in managing complex engineering and manufacturing operations will be instrumental in Boeing's turnaround efforts.\n\nBoeing, a leading global aerospace company, develops, manufactures, and services commercial airplanes, defense products, and space systems for customers in over 150 countries. As a top U.S. exporter, Boeing leverages the talents of a global supplier base to advance economic opportunity, sustainability, and community impact.\n\n(With inputs from Reuters)", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8252684935", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:59:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:59:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:58:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/boeing-names-ceo-losses-more-124658203.html", "title": "Boeing names new CEO after losses more than triple", "body": "Boeing named a new CEO after it reported a core operating loss of $1.4 billion in the second quarter - more than triple the loss from a year ago - as increased scrutiny of the safety and quality of its planes kept the troubled company from making enough aircraft to return to profitability.\n\nBoeing announced Robert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, the former CEO of supplier Rockwell Collins, will be its new CEO, effective August 8, replacing retiring Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun, who has been under fire for the company's problems. Ortberg has a background as an engineer, not in finance, having earned his college degree in mechanical engineering.\n\n\"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" said Ortberg in a statement from the company. \"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront.\"\n\nOrtberg, who noted \"there is much work to be done\" at Boeing, has a background that could be encouraging to some staff who have criticized Boeing's management for having too much of a emphasis on finance rather than the engineering quality.\n\nBut Ortberg's appointment doesn't necessarily guarantee the right decisions will be made by the company's new leadership. While Calhoun's background is in finance, his predecessor, Dennis Muilenburg, the CEO of Boeing at the time of the development of the troubled 737 Max jet and the two fatal crashes of the plane that led to its 20-month grounding and five years of financial losses, also had an engineering background.\n\nOrtberg started work in the aviation industry in 1983 as an engineer at Texas Instruments, and then joined Rockwell Collins in 1987 as a program manager. He became CEO of Rockwell Collins in 2013, and retired from the company in 2021.\n\n\"Kelly is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies,\" said Boeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf in a statement. \"We look forward to working with him as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in its long history.\"\n\nRockwell Collins provides avionics, the electrical systems used on aircraft, and information technology used in the aerospace industry. It was purchased by United Technologies in 2018 and now operates as Collins Aerospace. Ortberg stayed with the company for three years as it was integrated into United Technologies, and then he retired.\n\nOrtberg will have his hands full fixing the problems at Boeing, which has not posted a profitable year since 2019. Since then, its core operating losses totaled $33.3 billion, including the loss announced Wednesday. Boeing will have difficulty returning to profitability until it can convince regulators that it has fixed problems with the safety and quality of its jets.\n\nThe company has admitted that two 737 Max crashes in October of 2018 and March of 2019 that killed a total of 346 people were the result of a design flaw. The crashes and the time it took to fix the design flaw resulted in a 20-month grounding of the plane that cost the company more than $20 billion.\n\nIt recently agreed to plead guilty to charges that its employees defrauded the Federal Aviation Administration during the original certification process for the 737 Max. As part of the guilty plea, Boeing agreed to operate under the supervision of a court-appointed monitor.\n\nThe company has come under renewed scrutiny since a 737 Max plane's door plug blew off shortly after takeoff in January. More than a dozen whistleblowers have told Congressional investigators about bad practices at Boeing, including the use of parts that did not mean standards. Many said Boeing retaliated against employees who complained about safety practices.\n\nThe company has agreed to an FAA demand to curb production of the 737 Max until the regulator is satisfied it has fixed its safety and quality issues. But that will keep the losses building at Boeing as it can't make money at its current level of production.\n\nBoeing's problems go beyond the 737 Max issues. The company also has problems with its defense business, which resulted in $913 million in losses on its defense, space and security unit, nearly double the $527 million it lost there a year earlier.\n\nIts Starliner space ship made its first crewed flight in the quarter but developed problems after docking at the International Space Station, leaving its two astronauts stuck at the ISS with no date yet known for its return.\n\nBoeing also reported it had additional losses in its program to deliver two new 747 jets that will be used as the new Air Force One planes by the president. That contract has already cost Boeing more than $2 billion going into the quarter. It said Wednesday that increased engineering costs for that contract and for the Starliner contributed to Boeing's increased losses.", "source": {"uri": "finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! Finance"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Aerospace_and_Defense/Aeronautical", "label": "dmoz/Business/Aerospace and Defense/Aeronautical", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Financial_Services/Leasing_Services", "label": "dmoz/Business/Financial Services/Leasing Services", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://media.zenfs.com/en/cnn_business_articles_218/d9e42c222c80906c2f54fe0e9bd771fe", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9771357", "eventUri": "eng-9771357", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-08", "textStart": 409, "textEnd": 417}], "sentiment": 0.1058823529411765, "wgt": 209, "relevance": 1}

Revenue fell 15% from a year earlier, and both its commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the Max, two of which crashed, killing 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration has increased its oversight of the company following mistakes including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet. It is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety.\n\nThe company is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. And it faces a multibillion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nOrtberg will become CEO and president on Aug. 8, Boeing said. His appointment comes as Boeing attempts to rebound from a...\n\nBoeing named former Rockwell Collins chief Robert \"Kelly\" Ortberg its next CEO Wednesday, as the aviation giant reported a hefty loss on continued operational problems.\n\nOrtberg, 64, helped lead Rockwell Collins and integrate it into United Technology prior to his retirement from RTX in 2021.\n\nHis appointment comes as Boeing attempts to rebound from a series of safety and quality control problems that have sharpened scrutiny of the company.\n\nOrtberg \"is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry,\" said Boeing chairman Steve Mollenkopf in a message to employees.\n\nOrtberg is set to become CEO on August 8, taking over for Dave Calhoun, a former General Electric and private equity executive who has held the post since early 2020.\n\n\"We look forward to working with Kelly as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in our long history,\" Mollenkopf said.\n\nBoeing on Wednesday reported a second-quarter loss of $1.4 billion, compared with a loss of $149 million in the year-ago period.\n\nRevenues fell 14.6 percent to $16.9 billion.\n\nThe quarterly results reflected a continued drag from Boeing's commercial division, where it has lowered production while addressing safety and quality control issues under the close watch of regulators.\n\nBoeing has been in the hot seat since a January incident in which a 737 MAX operated by Alaska Airlines made an emergency landing after a fuselage panel blew out mid-flight.\n\nBoeing's latest results also showed significant weakness in its defense business due to a number of fixed price contracts where it has experienced deep losses due to supply chain problems, as well as higher engineering costs and stabilize our operations,\" Calhoun said. \"We are making important progress in our recovery and will continue to build trust through action and transparency.\"\n\nShares of Boeing rose 1.7 percent in {"uri": "8252704909", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:11:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:11:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:11:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://buffalonews.com/news/nation-world/business/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-loss-of-more-than-1-4-billion-in/article_95eef885-c389-52df-a740-a7b0b1a08e37.html", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts loss of more than $1.4 billion in second quarter", "body": "By DAVID KOENIG - AP Airlines Writer\n\nBoeing named a longtime aerospace industry veteran on Wednesday as its next chief executive, who will take over a company that has been rocked by legal, regulatory and production problems.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, a former CEO at Boeing supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun as CEO and president effective Aug. 8, the company said. Calhoun announced in March that he would retire at the end of the year, and analysts generally praised the quicker transition.\n\nBoeing named its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nPeople are also reading... Kim Pegula greets Bills players, coaches after training camp practice: 'That's still the Mama Bear' Erie County prosecutor charged with misconduct, fired from DA's office Another property near the new Bills stadium is going up for sale End of an era as Rev. Jud Weiksnar departs, leaving Buffalo without Franciscans for first time in 166 years The NFL hopes its radical new kickoff rule produces excitement. Here's how it will work Under pressure: Some Bills fans feeling angst over new stadium season ticket decision Kenmore East sophomore dies after being hit while riding bicycle Judge dismisses lawsuit filed by Dunkirk mother drug tested without consent at Children's Hospital Mystery still unsolved: Niagara Falls Police conclude probe into Rainbow Bridge crash that killed couple Erie County real estate transactions Price hike: Seat prices doubling at new Bills stadium for some club season ticket holders Man hospitalized with severe leg injury after Chautauqua Lake boating mishap Bills linebacker Matt Milano outlines long road back: 'I trust myself and my work' Historic downtown office building that received millions to renovate needs millions more Orchard Park judge sentences shoplifter to a year in jail: An appropriate case 'to make an example'\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty this month to a federal fraud charge in connection with its 737 Max jetliner and two crashes that killed 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration increased its oversight of the company after the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet raised manufacturing quality concerns.\n\nBoeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\" Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies, Mollenkopf said.\n\nThe company waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg, a spokesperson said. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nOrtberg emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial airplanes division.\n\nOrtberg led Rockwell Collins from 2013 to 2018, when it merged with United Technologies and wound up as part of RTX, the company formerly known as Raytheon. He retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nRichard Aboulafia, a longtime aerospace analyst and consultant and recently a harsh critic of the company, said the hire is great news for Boeing.\n\n\"He is a deeply respected leader in the aerospace industry, and brings more hope for a better future than the company has enjoyed in decades,\" Aboulafia said.\n\nDeutsche Bank analyst Scott Deuschle said Ortberg \"has an engineering background, experience in the aviation industry, and experience as a public company CEO.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | Stitcher | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIn a statement issued by Boeing, Ortberg said, \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nCalhoun will serve as a special adviser to the Boeing board until next March.\n\nLike Calhoun, who took over as CEO in the wake of the two Max crashes, Ortberg will inherit the leadership of a company facing ongoing crises and criticism from inside and outside the company. Boeing has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety. It is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It faces a threatened strike this fall by its largest union, the International Association of Machinists.\n\nThe company is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nThe quarterly earnings reported Wednesday reflect the continuing challenges at Boeing. The company reported a loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier.\n\nExcluding special items, the loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion.\n\nThe commercial-airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA has limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners since shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine that it would pay as part of an agreement with the Justice Department to plead guilty to fraud in connection with development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the deal, which is opposed by many families of those who died in the two Max crashes.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. The smaller services business earned $870 million.\n\nBoeing shares rose 2% in morning trading.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8252438420", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:27:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:27:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:22:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://keyt.com/news/money-and-business/cnn-business-consumer/2024/07/31/boeing-names-new-ceo-after-losses-more-than-triple/", "title": "Boeing names new CEO after losses more than triple", "body": "New York (CNN) -- Boeing named a new CEO after it reported a core operating loss of $1.4 billion in the second quarter - more than triple the loss from a year ago - as increased scrutiny of the safety and quality of its planes kept the troubled company from making enough aircraft to return to profitability.\n\nBoeing announced Robert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, the former CEO of supplier Rockwell Collins, will be its new CEO, effective August 8, replacing retiring Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun, who has been under fire for the company's problems. Ortberg has a background as an engineer, not in finance, having earned his college degree in mechanical engineering.\n\n\"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" said Ortberg in a statement from the company. \"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront.\"\n\nOrtberg, who noted \"there is much work to be done\" at Boeing, has a background that could be encouraging to some staff who have criticized Boeing's management for having too much of a emphasis on finance rather than the engineering quality.\n\nBut Ortberg's appointment doesn't necessarily guarantee the right decisions will be made by the company's new leadership. While Calhoun's background is in finance, his predecessor, Dennis Muilenburg, the CEO of Boeing at the time of the development of the troubled 737 Max jet and the two fatal crashes of the plane that led to its 20-month grounding and five years of financial losses, also had an engineering background.\n\nOrtberg started work in the aviation industry in 1983 as an engineer at Texas Instruments, and then joined Rockwell Collins in 1987 as a program manager. He became CEO of Rockwell Collins in 2013, and retired from the company in 2021.\n\n\"Kelly is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies,\" said Boeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf in a statement. \"We look forward to working with him as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in its long history.\"\n\nRockwell Collins provides avionics, the electrical systems used on aircraft, and information technology used in the aerospace industry. It was purchased by United Technologies in 2018 and now operates as Collins Aerospace. Ortberg stayed with the company for three years as it was integrated into United Technologies, and then he retired.\n\nHe will have his hands full fixing the problems at Boeing, which has not posted a profitable year since 2019. Since then, its core operating losses totaled $33.3 billion, including the loss announced Wednesday. Boeing will have difficulty returning to profitability until it can convince regulators that it has fixed problems with the safety and quality of its jets.\n\n- This is a developing story, it will be updated.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "8252568649", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:44:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:44:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:43:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "http://sentinelcolorado.com/sentinel-biz-news/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-a-loss-of-more-than-1-4-billion-in-second-quarter/", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts a loss of more than $1.4 billion in second quarter - Sentinel Colorado", "body": "The loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nBoeing named a longtime aerospace industry veteran as its next chief executive, who will take over a company that has been rocked by legal, regulatory and production problems.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, 64, a former CEO at aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun, 67, as CEO effective Aug. 8, the company said on Wednesday.\n\nBoeing announced its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the Max, two of which crashed, killing 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration has increased its oversight of the company following mistakes including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet. It is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety.\n\nThe company is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nOrtberg will become CEO and president on Aug. 8, Boeing said. He emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial-airplanes division.\n\nChairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\"\n\nMollenkopf said Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies.\n\nA Boeing spokesperson said the company had waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, reported a loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier.\n\nExcluding special items, the loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion.\n\nThe commercial-airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA has limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners since shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine that it would pay as part of an agreement with the Justice Department to plead guilty to fraud in connection with development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the deal, which is opposed by many families of those who died in the two Max crashes.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. The smaller services business earned $870 million.", "source": {"uri": "sentinelcolorado.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sentinel Colorado"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8252395508", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:57:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:57:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:57:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://gulfbusiness.com/boeing-industry-veteran-kelly-ortberg-ceo/", "title": "Boeing names industry veteran Kelly Ortberg as CEO", "body": "Image credit: Sourced from Boeing\n\nBoeing, on Wednesday, named aerospace industry veteran Kelly Ortberg as its new president and CEO, tasking the former Rockwell Collins executive in turning around the struggling planemaker, after it reported a $1.4bn loss.\n\nOrtberg will assume his duties on August 8, Boeing said.\n\nHe will succeed Dave Calhoun, who earlier this year announced his intention to retire from the company, having served as president and CEO since January 2020, and as a member of Boeing's Board of Directors since 2009.\n\n\"The Board conducted a thorough and extensive search process over the last several months to select the next CEO of Boeing and Kelly has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter,\" said Steven Mollenkopf, chair of the Board.\n\n\"Kelly is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies. We look forward to working with him as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in its long history.\"\n\n\"The Board would also like to thank Dave Calhoun for his strong leadership at Boeing, first as Chair and then as CEO, when he stepped in to steer the company through the challenges of recent years,\" added Mollenkopf.\n\n\"I'm extremely honoured and humbled to join this iconic company,\" said Ortberg. \"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront. There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nOrtberg, 64, brings over 35 years of aerospace leadership to this position, added the aircraft manufacturer's official statement.\n\nFinancial results\n\nThe company also posted a bigger quarterly loss, as its troubled defence and space business exacerbated the financial strain on the US planemaker that has already scaled back commercial aircraft production to tackle a quality crisis.\n\nBoeing's Defence, Space and Security unit, one of its three main businesses, has lost billions of dollars in 2023 and 2022, which executives attributed to cost overruns on fixed-price contracts.\n\nSuch contracts have high margins but leave defence contractors vulnerable to inflationary pressures that have dented US corporate earnings in the last few years.\n\nThe planemaker used to bid aggressively for fixed-price contracts before the pandemic, but has now said it would pivot away from such contracts to stem losses at the business, which amounted to $1.76bn last year.\n\nAhead of last week's Farnborough Air Show, the unit's head had said it was \"significantly challenged\" during the quarter.\n\nBoeing CFO Brian West said, in May, the planemaker will burn rather than generate cash in 2024, hamstrung by lower jet deliveries compared to last year.\n\nBoeing's ongoing crisis\n\nThe company is mired in crisis after a cabin panel on a 737 MAX 9 jets blew off midair in January, which led to a slowdown in production of its top-selling plane and a management shakeup, even as it came under intense regulatory and legal scrutiny.\n\nThe US aviation regulator has capped production of 737 MAX jets at 38 per month, though Reuters has reported that Boeing has been producing jets during some weeks at a much lower level.\n\nThat has led to lower deliveries, frustrating customers.\n\nDuring the second quarter, Boeing delivered a total of 92 aircraft, down 32 per cent from last year.\n\nRead: {"uri": "8252568379", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:44:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:44:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:43:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/07/31/nx-s1-5058497/boeing-ceo-737max-kelly-ortberg", "title": "Boeing names aerospace veteran Kelly Ortberg as its next CEO", "body": "Boeing 737 MAX airplanes sit on the assembly line at the company's facility in Renton, Wash. Jennifer Buchanan/The Seattle Times via AP hide caption\n\nAfter a lengthy search, Boeing has tapped aerospace industry veteran Robert \"Kelly\" Ortberg as its next CEO, the company announced Wednesday.\n\nOrtberg will start the job on Aug. 8, replacing retiring CEO Dave Calhoun, who has been under fire as the company's commercial airplane and defense programs continue to struggle.\n\nBoeing will now turn to Ortberg to lead its turnaround plans. He has a background in engineering, not finance, having earned a mechanical engineering degree at the University of Iowa. That may help assuage the concerns of critics who say Boeing's leadership has been too focused on financial results and not enough on engineering quality.\n\n\"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" Ortberg said in a statement. \"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront. There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nThe job facing Ortberg is daunting. Boeing reported a bigger quarterly loss and weaker revenue than analysts were expecting during the second quarter. The aerospace giant reported a net loss of $1.44 billion in the second quarter, as increased scrutiny of its production lines has limited production of its bestselling 737 Max jets.\n\n\"Despite a challenging quarter, we are making substantial progress strengthening our quality management system and positioning our company for the future,\" Calhoun said. \"While we have more work ahead, the steps we're taking will help stabilize our operations and ensure Boeing is the company the world needs it to be.\"\n\nBoeing's board Chair Steve Mollenkopf announced the new CEO in a message to employees.\n\n\"The Board conducted a thorough and extensive search process over the last several months to select the next CEO of Boeing and Kelly has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter,\" Mollenkopf wrote. \"He is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies.\"\n\nOrtberg, 64, is just a few years younger than the company's outgoing leader. Boeing's board had previously extended its mandatory retirement age from 65 to 70 to allow Calhoun, now 67, to stay on as CEO.\n\nOrtberg's career in the aviation industry started at Texas Instruments. He joined Rockwell Collins in 1987 and rose through the ranks to become CEO in 2013. He oversaw mergers with United Technology and RTX (formerly Raytheon) before retiring from the company in 2021.", "source": {"uri": "npr.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "NPR"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8252416543", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:13:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:13:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:09:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://kion546.com/money/cnn-business-consumer/2024/07/31/boeing-names-new-ceo-after-losses-more-than-triple/", "title": "Boeing names new CEO after losses more than triple - KION546", "body": "New York (CNN) -- Boeing named a new CEO after it reported a core operating loss of $1.4 billion in the second quarter - more than triple the loss from a year ago - as increased scrutiny of the safety and quality of its planes kept the troubled company from making enough aircraft to return to profitability.\n\nBoeing announced Robert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, the former CEO of supplier Rockwell Collins, will be its new CEO, effective August 8, replacing retiring Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun, who has been under fire for the company's problems. Ortberg has a background as an engineer, not in finance, having earned his college degree in mechanical engineering.\n\n\"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" said Ortberg in a statement from the company. \"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront.\"\n\nOrtberg, who noted \"there is much work to be done\" at Boeing, has a background that could be encouraging to some staff who have criticized Boeing's management for having too much of a emphasis on finance rather than the engineering quality.\n\nBut Ortberg's appointment doesn't necessarily guarantee the right decisions will be made by the company's new leadership. While Calhoun's background is in finance, his predecessor, Dennis Muilenburg, the CEO of Boeing at the time of the development of the troubled 737 Max jet and the two fatal crashes of the plane that led to its 20-month grounding and five years of financial losses, also had an engineering background.\n\nOrtberg started work in the aviation industry in 1983 as an engineer at Texas Instruments, and then joined Rockwell Collins in 1987 as a program manager. He became CEO of Rockwell Collins in 2013, and retired from the company in 2021.\n\n\"Kelly is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies,\" said Boeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf in a statement. \"We look forward to working with him as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in its long history.\"\n\n- This is a developing story, it will be updated.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "2024-07-439592005", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:32:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:32:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:44:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-a-loss-of-more-than-1-4-billion/article_94dd0ee0-d27e-55bd-9715-779dd34a24b6.html", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts a loss of more than $1.4 billion in second quarter", "body": "Boeing named a longtime aerospace industry veteran as its next chief executive, who will take over a company that has been rocked by legal, regulatory and production problems.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, 64, a former CEO at aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun, 67, as CEO effective Aug. 8, the company said on Wednesday.\n\nBoeing announced its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the Max, two of which crashed, killing 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration has increased its oversight of the company following mistakes including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet. It is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety.\n\nThe company is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nOrtberg will become CEO and president on Aug. 8, Boeing said. He emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial-airplanes division.\n\nChairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\"\n\nMollenkopf said Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies.\n\nA Boeing spokesperson said the company had waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, reported a loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier.\n\nExcluding special items, the loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion.\n\nThe commercial-airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA has limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners since shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine that it would pay as part of an agreement with the Justice Department to plead guilty to fraud in connection with development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the deal, which is opposed by many families of those who died in the two Max crashes.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. The smaller services business earned $870 million.\n\nBoeing shares added 2% in premarket trading.\n\nMore from this section\n\nACES Quality Management Enhances ACES Deposit Account Audit Pack for Banks and Credit Unions\n\nChampioning Environmental Change: California Safe Schools Fosters Collaboration and Innovation\n\nLinguist Jeff Siegel Publishes Comprehensive Nama Dictionary", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "david_koenig@kulr8.com", "name": "David Koenig", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [], "categories": [], "image": "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/kulr8.com/content/tncms/custom/image/ebec0578-57d0-11ee-978f-b7da313020af.jpg?resize=600%2C315", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9771357", "eventUri": "eng-9771357", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-08", "textStart": 307, "textEnd": 313, "freq": 2}], "sentiment": -0.2705882352941177, "wgt": 204, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8252685584", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:59:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:59:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:59:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-loss-of-more-than-1-4-billion-in/article_79de4083-65e2-5577-86aa-565c03ce9ec0.html", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts loss of more than $1.4 billion in second quarter", "body": "By DAVID KOENIG - AP Airlines Writer\n\nBoeing named a longtime aerospace industry veteran on Wednesday as its next chief executive, who will take over a company that has been rocked by legal, regulatory and production problems.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, a former CEO at Boeing supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun as CEO and president effective Aug. 8, the company said. Calhoun announced in March that he would retire at the end of the year, and analysts generally praised the quicker transition.\n\nBoeing named its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nPeople are also reading... Rosie's Pub owner leaves beloved downtown business after 21 years Bloomington approves $6.8M contract for roadwork REO Speedwagon, Loverboy to perform in Bloomington this fall 17-year-old McLean County teen charged as an adult for attempted murder Bear seen in Illinois likely swam across Ohio River from Kentucky, wildlife official says Bloomington man denied release from treatment center 15 years after infant daughter's death 2 suspects arrested after shots fired on Morris Avenue in Bloomington Bloomington woman pleads guilty to burglary charge in McLean County Bloomington businessman giving backpacks to families in need Records show deputy's behavior, integrity questioned years before shooting of Sonya Massey UPDATE: Missing teen from Normal found safe Funerals pending for July 27 2 men detained in McLean County after highway shooting in Bloomington Bloomington native, trick rider Lindy Lica performs hometown show at McLean County Fair Record of deputy who killed Sonya Massey should have raised flags, experts say\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty this month to a federal fraud charge in connection with its 737 Max jetliner and two crashes that killed 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration increased its oversight of the company after the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet raised manufacturing quality concerns.\n\nBoeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\" Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies, Mollenkopf said.\n\nThe company waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg, a spokesperson said. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nOrtberg emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial airplanes division.\n\nOrtberg led Rockwell Collins from 2013 to 2018, when it merged with United Technologies and wound up as part of RTX, the company formerly known as Raytheon. He retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nRichard Aboulafia, a longtime aerospace analyst and consultant and recently a harsh critic of the company, said the hire is great news for Boeing.\n\n\"He is a deeply respected leader in the aerospace industry, and brings more hope for a better future than the company has enjoyed in decades,\" Aboulafia said.\n\nDeutsche Bank analyst Scott Deuschle said Ortberg \"has an engineering background, experience in the aviation industry, and experience as a public company CEO.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIn a statement issued by Boeing, Ortberg said, \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nCalhoun will serve as a special adviser to the Boeing board until next March.\n\nLike Calhoun, who took over as CEO in the wake of the two Max crashes, Ortberg will inherit the leadership of a company facing ongoing crises and criticism from inside and outside the company. Boeing has lost more than $25 billion since the start of 2019.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety. It is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It faces a threatened strike this fall by its largest union, the International Association of Machinists.\n\nThe company is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nThe quarterly earnings reported Wednesday reflect the continuing challenges at Boeing. The company reported a loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier.\n\nExcluding special items, the loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion.\n\nThe commercial-airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA has limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners since shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine that it would pay as part of an agreement with the Justice Department to plead guilty to fraud in connection with development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the deal, which is opposed by many families of those who died in the two Max crashes.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. The smaller services business earned $870 million.\n\nBoeing shares rose 2% in morning trading.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8252496036", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:59:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:59:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:58:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://wtop.com/national/2024/07/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-a-loss-of-more-than-1-4-billion-in-second-quarter/", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts a loss of more than $1.4 billion in second quarter - WTOP News", "body": "Boeing lost more than $1.4 billion in the second quarter and said a longtime industry executive will take over as...\n\nBoeing lost more than $1.4 billion in the second quarter and said a longtime industry executive will take over as chief executive of the troubled aircraft manufacturer next week.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, 64, a former CEO at aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun as CEO, the company said.\n\nShares rose more than 2% before the opening bell Wednesday.\n\nBoeing's loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected. Revenue fell 15% from a year earlier, and both its commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the Max, two of which crashed, killing 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration has increased its oversight of the company following mistakes including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet. It is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety.\n\nThe company is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nOrtberg will become CEO and president on Aug. 8, Boeing said. He emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial-airplanes division.\n\nChairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after \"a thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\"\n\nMollenkopf said Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. problems.\n\nOrtberg, 64, helped lead Rockwell Collins and integrate it into United Technology prior to his retirement from RTX in 2021.\n\nHis appointment comes as Boeing attempts to rebound from a series of safety and quality control problems that have sharpened scrutiny on the company.\n\nOrtberg \"is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry,\" said Boeing chairman Steve Mollenkopf in a message to employees.\n\nOrtberg is set to become CEO on August 8, taking over for Dave Calhoun, a former General Electric and private equity executive who has held the post since early 2020.\n\n\"We look forward to working with Kelly as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in our long history,\" Mollenkopf said.\n\nBoeing on Wednesday reported a second-quarter loss of $1.4 billion, compared with a loss of $149 million in the year-ago period.\n\nRevenues fell 14.6 percent to $16.9 billion.\n\nThe quarterly results reflected a continued drag from Boeing's commercial division, where it has lowered production while addressing safety and quality control issues under the close watch of regulators.\n\nBoeing has been in the hot seat since a January incident in which a 737 MAX operated by Alaska Airlines made an emergency landing after a fuselage panel blew out mid-flight.\n\nBoeing's latest results also showed significant weakness in its defense business due to several fixed price contracts where it has experienced deep losses due to supply chain problems, as well as higher engineering costs and technical issues.\n\nBoeing's press release listed four defense contracts behind an operating loss of $913 million in the quarter.\n\n\"While we have more work ahead, the steps we're taking will help stabilize our operations,\" Calhoun {"uri": "8252491122", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:56:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:56:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:55:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/31/boeing-picks-aerospace-executive-kelly-ortberg-as-its-next-ceo/", "title": "Boeing picks aerospace executive Kelly Ortberg as its next CEO", "body": "Boeing said it has tapped aerospace executive Robert K. \"Kelly\" Ortberg as its next president and chief executive, replacing outgoing CEO Dave Calhoun in the wake of increased regulatory scrutiny sparked by the aircraft manufacturer's production problems.\n\nOrtberg, 64, is the former CEO of Rockwell Collins, an aerospace company that was a supplier of avionics systems for Boeing. Ortberg served as the head of Rockwell Collins from 2013 through its integration with United Technologies and RTX, until he retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nOrtberg's appointment will be effective as of August 8, Boeing said Wednesday in a statement. .\n\nThe appointment comes four months after Calhoun announced he would be stepping down as the CEO of Boeing following a mid-air blowout of a door panel on one of its Boeing 737 Max 9 planes, which spurred scrutiny from regulators and lawmakers. Calhoun had joined the company with the mandate to steady the business following two deadly crashes of Boeing aircraft in 2018 and 2019, to which Boeing earlier this month agreed to plead guilty to a criminal fraud charge.\n\nIn a statement, Ortberg said the company is facing \"much work to be done.\" He added he is committed to working with the company's 170,000 employees \"with safety and quality at the forefront.\"\n\nSeparately, Boeing reported that it lost more than $1.4 billion in the second quarter, a wider loss than expected by Wall Street. The Federal Aviation Administration has increased its oversight of the company following mistakes including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet. {"uri": "8252437697", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:23:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:23:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:22:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://whdh.com/news/boeing-names-new-ceo-after-losses-more-than-triple/", "title": "Boeing names new CEO after losses more than triple - Boston News, Weather, Sports | WHDH 7News", "body": "New York (CNN) -- Boeing named a new CEO after it reported a core operating loss of $1.4 billion in the second quarter - more than triple the loss from a year ago - as increased scrutiny of the safety and quality of its planes kept the troubled company from making enough aircraft to return to profitability.\n\nBoeing announced Robert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, the former CEO of supplier Rockwell Collins, will be its new CEO, effective August 8, replacing retiring Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun, who has been under fire for the company's problems. Ortberg has a background as an engineer, not in finance, having earned his college degree in mechanical engineering.\n\n\"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" said Ortberg in a statement from the company. \"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront.\"\n\nOrtberg, who noted \"there is much work to be done\" at Boeing, has a background that could be encouraging to some staff who have criticized Boeing's management for having too much of a emphasis on finance rather than the engineering quality.\n\nBut Ortberg's appointment doesn't necessarily guarantee the right decisions will be made by the company's new leadership. While Calhoun's background is in finance, his predecessor, Dennis Muilenburg, the CEO of Boeing at the time of the development of the troubled 737 Max jet and the two fatal crashes of the plane that led to its 20-month grounding and five years of financial losses, also had an engineering background.\n\nOrtberg started work in the aviation industry in 1983 as an engineer at Texas Instruments, and then joined Rockwell Collins in 1987 as a program manager. He became CEO of Rockwell Collins in 2013, and retired from the company in 2021.\n\n\"Kelly is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies,\" said Boeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf in a statement. \"We look forward to working with him as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in its long history.\"\n\n(Copyright (c) 2024 CNN. {"uri": "8252732336", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:30:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:30:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:29:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-loss-of-more-than-1-4-billion-in/article_a8be986f-4928-545f-aa49-d3f41cad6874.html", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts loss of more than $1.4 billion in second quarter", "body": "By DAVID KOENIG - AP Airlines Writer\n\nBoeing named a longtime aerospace industry veteran Wednesday as its next chief executive, who will take over a company rocked by legal, regulatory and production problems and mounting financial repercussions.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, a former CEO at Boeing supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun as CEO and president effective Aug. 8, the company said. Calhoun said in March that he would retire at the end of the year, and analysts generally praised the quicker transition.\n\nBoeing announced its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and the company's revenue lower than Wall Street's dismal expectations, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nWho's Donald Trump's pick for Missouri governor? He's got three. Inside the ouster: Why the St. Louis Public Schools leader was pushed out after 1 year St. Louis Public Schools superintendent Keisha Scarlett is out, replaced with interim chief Cardinals land starter Erick Fedde and Tommy Pham, but trade Tommy Edman in 3-team deal Mercy paid former exec $1 million in wake of 'sexual exploitation' allegations Ranch in Wildwood is sanctuary for abused miniature horses Mine collapse leaves Alton golf course shut down, paying six figures a month Hair relaxer ingredients tied to cancer risk, say lawsuits and FDA. St. Louis stylists offer options. St. Louis County lawsuit names Omaha archbishop among sexual abusers. He denies the claim. Editorial: Bell has our enthusiastic endorsement for Missouri's 1st Congressional District Tommy Edman reflects on time in St. Louis after an 'abrupt ending': Cardinals Extra How Cardinals capitalized on 3-team deal to acquire 2 needs, Erick Fedde and Tommy Pham Goold's chat: What 3 ways could Cardinals assert themselves as contenders? Is trade only 1? Cardinals broadcaster Bally secures Comcast deal, clearing major hurdle in bankruptcy plan At the buzzer, Cardinals send Dylan Carlson to Tampa Bay for reliever Shawn Armstrong\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing, which is the subject of multiple investigations into its safety culture and manufacturing quality.\n\nThe American aerospace giant agreed to plead guilty this month to a federal fraud charge in connection with its 737 Max jetliner and two crashes that killed 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration increased its oversight of the company and limited the number of planes it could produce after a panel blew off an Alaska Airlines Max flying at an altitude of 16,000 feet. No one was seriously hurt, but the frightening incident and subsequent scrutiny have damaged Boeing's reputation.\n\nBoeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\" Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies, Mollenkopf said.\n\nThe company waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg, a spokesperson said. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nOrtberg emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial airplanes division.\n\nOrtberg led Rockwell Collins from 2013 to 2018, when it merged with United Technologies and wound up as part of RTX, the company formerly known as Raytheon. He retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nRichard Aboulafia, a longtime aerospace analyst and consultant and recently a harsh critic of the company, said the hire is great news for Boeing.\n\n\"He is a deeply respected leader in the aerospace industry, and brings more hope for a better future than the company has enjoyed in decades,\" Aboulafia said.\n\nDeutsche Bank analyst Scott Deuschle said Ortberg \"has an engineering background, experience in the aviation industry, and experience as a public company CEO.\"\n\nIn a statement issued by Boeing, Ortberg said, \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nCalhoun will serve as a special adviser to the Boeing board until next March.\n\nLike Calhoun, who took over as CEO in the wake of the two Max crashes, Ortberg inherits the leadership of a company facing ongoing crises and criticism from inside and outside the company.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety. It is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It faces a threatened strike this fall by its largest union, the International Association of Machinists.\n\nThe company is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nThe quarterly earnings reported Wednesday reflected the continuing challenges at Boeing. The reported loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier. Since the start of 2019, Boeing has lost more than $25 billion.\n\nExcluding special items, the second-quarter loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion. The commercial airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million, and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine it agreed to pay as part of its plea deal with the Justice Department in connection with development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the agreement, which also calls for the appointment of an independent compliance monitor and for Boeing to invest at least $455 million \"in its compliance, quality, and safety programs.\"\n\nMany families of the people who died in the two Max crashes, which took place off the coast of Indonesia in 2018 and in Ethiopia less than five months later, oppose the deal and plan to ask the judge to reject it.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. The smaller services business earned $870 million.\n\nBoeing shares rose 2% in morning trading.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. company said on Wednesday.\n\nBoeing's loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected.\n\nRevenue fell 15 per cent from a year earlier, and both its commercial-aeroplanes business and helped lead Rockwell Collins and integrate it into United Technology prior to his retirement from RTX in 2021.\n\nHis appointment comes as Boeing attempts to rebound from a series of safety and quality control problems that have sharpened scrutiny on the company.\n\nOrtberg \"is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry,\" said Boeing chairman Steve Mollenkopf in a message to employees.\n\nOrtberg is set to become CEO on August 8, taking over for Dave Calhoun, a former General Electric and private equity executive who has held the post since early 2020.\n\n\"We look forward to working with Kelly as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in our long history,\" Mollenkopf said.\n\nBoeing on Wednesday reported a second-quarter loss of $1.4 billion, compared with a loss of $149 million in the year-ago period.\n\nRevenues fell 14.6 percent to $16.9 billion.\n\nThe quarterly results reflected a continued drag from Boeing's commercial division, where it has lowered production while addressing safety and quality control issues under the close watch of regulators.\n\nBoeing has been in the hot seat since a January incident in which a 737 MAX operated by Alaska Airlines made an emergency landing after a fuselage panel blew out mid-flight.\n\nBoeing's latest results also showed significant weakness in its defense business due to a number of fixed price contracts where it has experienced deep losses due to supply chain problems, as well as higher engineering costs and technical issues.\n\nBoeing's press release listed four defense contracts behind an operating loss of $913 million in the quarter.\n\n\"While we have more work ahead, the steps we're taking will help stabilize our operations,\" Calhoun said. \"We are
