{"uri": "8252554125", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:34:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:34:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:34:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.dailysabah.com/business/transportation/boeing-names-new-ceo-to-steer-turnaround-amid-safety-crisis", "title": "Boeing names new CEO to steer turnaround amid safety crisis", "body": "U.S. aerospace giant Boeing named on Wednesday industry veteran Kelly Ortberg as its new president and CEO after a monthslong search, tasking the former Rockwell Collins executive with the monumental job of turning around the struggling planemaker.\n\nOrtberg, 64, will start on Aug. 8 and face a multitude of issues, including reviving jet production and rebuilding trust with regulators, the industry and the flying public. Shares rose 2.9% before the bell.\n\nBoeing, one of two global plane makers, has been mired in a reputational and safety crisis after a Jan. 5 midair panel blowout on an Alaska Airlines-operated Max 9 jet carrying 171 passengers. It posted a $1.4 billion loss in the second quarter as it continues to burn cash.\n\nThe accident eventually led to the resignation of CEO Dave Calhoun and the departure of the company's previous board president as regulators took aim at the safety culture that was already shaken by previous crashes in 2018 and 2019.\n\nShortly after the accident, the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) barred Boeing from expanding production of its cash-cow 737 Max family of jets without estimating how long the limitation would last.\n\nThe U.S. aviation regulator capped production at 38 jets per month, though Reuters reported that Boeing had been producing jets at a much lower level for some weeks.\n\nOn Feb. 28, the regulator gave Boeing 90 days to develop a comprehensive plan to address \"systemic quality-control issues,\" which the company submitted in May.\n\nHowever, the FAA's administrator has said Boeing would not be immediately allowed to increase 737 Max production.\n\n\"During his leadership at Collins, he was well liked by employees and direct reports and very personable,\" Jefferies analysts said in a note from earlier this week, after industry publication the Air Current reported Ortberg was a serious contender.\n\nJefferies said he was a \"tough negotiator\" dealing with diverse customers and suppliers.\n\nA mechanical engineer, Ortberg has more than 30 years of experience in aerospace and defense, including numerous executive roles. After five years leading Rockwell Collins, he steered the company's integration with United Technologies and RTX until he retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nHe pipped Patrick Shanahan to one of the top industrial jobs after the former Spirit Aero CEO was seen as a favorite for succeeding Calhoun by some analysts and investors.\n\n\"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started,\" Ortberg said in a statement.\n\nDuring the second quarter, Boeing delivered 92 aircraft, down 32% from last year. It posted a loss of $2.33 a share, as its troubled defense and space business exacerbated the financial strain on the company.\n\nThe Defense, Space, and Security unit, one of Boeing's three main businesses, lost billions of dollars in 2023 and 2022. Executives attributed this to cost overruns on fixed-price contracts.\n\nSuch contracts have high margins but leave defense contractors vulnerable to inflationary pressures that have dented U.S. corporate earnings in the last few years.\n\nThe planemaker used to bid aggressively for fixed-price contracts before the pandemic but has now said it would pivot away from such contracts to stem losses at the business, which amounted to $1.76 billion last year.\n\nAhead of last week's Farnborough Air Show, the unit's head had said it was \"significantly challenged\" during the quarter.\n\nBoeing CFO Brian West said in May the planemaker will burn rather than generate cash in 2024, hamstrung by lower jet deliveries compared to last year.", "source": {"uri": "dailysabah.com", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/boeing-ceo-boss-rockwell-collins-1931437", "title": "Former Rockwell Collins Boss Enters Mix to Replace Boeing CEO", "body": "A new candidate has reportedly joined the race to succeed departing Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun, aiming to guide the company through a period marked by numerous scandals.\n\nKelly Ortberg has emerged as a contender for the top job at the beleaguered aircraft manufacturer, according to trade publication The Air Current, citing \"multiple industry officials.\"\n\nOrtberg is the former CEO of Rockwell Collins, a company which provided aviation systems and technology services to commercial customers and government agencies until it was purchased by United Technologies in November 2018.\n\nOrtberg currently serves on the board of directors of Aptiv, an automotive technology supplier, and as co-chair of the board of directors for FIRST, an organization which hosts annual high-school robotics competitions.\n\nNewsweek has contacted Boeing to inquire about Ortberg's candidacy, and to ask when the new CEO will be chosen.\n\nOrtberg joins a handful of other potential replacements for Dave Calhoun, who will be stepping down at the end of the year.\n\nCalhoun has led the aerospace giant since 2020, after his predecessor Dennis Muilenburg was fired in the wake of the 2018 and 2019 737 MAX crashes.\n\nIn March, however, Calhoun announced that he would be leaving the company, kicking off the search for his successor.\n\nHis announcement came amid increased scrutiny of the company following the January 5 incident in which a door plug blew off an Alaska Airlines Boeing aircraft mid-flight, and caused the airline to ground its entire fleet of 737 MAX 9s.\n\nBesides Ortberg, the other major contenders include Stephanie Pope and Patrick Shanahan.\n\nPope is currently the chief operating officer at Boeing, and CEO of the company's Commercial Airplanes division.\n\nAnalysts previously told Newsweek that Pope's tenure with Boeing - having joined the company in 1994 - made her a strong internal candidate.\n\nShanahan is the president and CEO of Spirit AeroSystems, and previously served as Acting U.S. Secretary of Defense between January and June 2019.\n\nShanahan became one of the favorites in early July, after Boeing agreed to buy back Spirit, the supplier which had spun off from the company in 2005, in a deal Boeing said was worth $8.3 billion.\n\nReuters also identified Boeing Chair Steve Mollenkopf as a potential replacement for Calhoun.\n\nErnest Arvai, president of aviation consultancy group AirInsight, previously told Newsweek that Pope and Shanahan's long-standing association with Boeing has deeply ingrained them in the company's culture, potentially hindering their ability to implement the wide-ranging changes that Boeing needs.\n\nBoeing has yet to make a decision, but industry sources told The Air Current that the company wants to {"uri": "8252697803", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:08:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:08:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:06:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.investing.com/news/stock-market-news/new-boeing-boss-kelly-ortberg-brings-engineering-background-aerospace-roots-3546346", "title": "New Boeing boss Kelly Ortberg brings engineering background, aerospace roots By Reuters", "body": "(Reuters) - Kelly Ortberg, the former Rockwell Collins (NYSE:COL) boss coming out of retirement to take the reins of Boeing (NYSE:BA), is known as an aerospace veteran with an engineering background that contrasts with the troubled planemaker's former leadership.\n\nOrtberg will have a lengthy to-do list when he starts on Aug. 8. He'll have to strengthen relations between Boeing and the airlines that are its biggest customers, and earn trust with the regulators and lawmakers that have put the company under a microscope following a January 5 mid-air panel blowout that turned into a full-blown safety crisis.\n\nOrtberg has a background that threads a delicate needle. He's a company outsider but an industry insider, which industry officials said positions him as able to change the company's culture without upending its aerospace roots.\n\nBut questions remained about whether he would drive radical change favored by some politicians and industry analysts.\n\nBob Jordan, CEO of Southwest Airlines (NYSE:LUV) said the company looks forward \"to working with Kelly Ortberg in his efforts to return Boeing to its place as the leading American aerospace company.\"\n\nOrtberg became CEO of key aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins in 2013 and steered the company's integration with United Technologies (NYSE:RTX) and RTX until his retirement in 2021. He also served as chair of the U.S. aerospace advocacy group Aerospace Industries Association (AIA) during the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\n\"This is as clear a break from the past as you can imagine,\" said Richard Aboulafia, analyst at consultancy AeroDynamic Advisory.\n\nIndustry insiders had previously hoped Boeing would hire someone on the younger side, in the expectation that it will take years to turn the company around. Ortberg is 64, however, and Boeing said it waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 just like it did for CEO Dave Calhoun, who is departing after a management shakeup earlier this year.\n\nAeroDynamic Advisory analyst Kevin Michaels, who first met Ortberg at Rockwell Collins in 1996, said Ortberg is young-looking and energetic and he didn't see his age as a barrier for the top job.\n\n\"We all thought that he retired too young,\" Michaels said.\n\nOrtberg is said to have beaten out Boeing Commercial Airplanes CEO Stephanie Pope and Spirit AeroSystems (NYSE:SPR) boss and former Boeing executive Pat Shanahan for the job.\n\n\"I think it's a positive,\" said one portfolio manager that holds Boeing stock. \"The narrative had been, 'I can't believe only Boeing insiders wanted this job.'\"\n\nBoeing had faced pressure from industry executives and U.S. lawmakers to choose new leadership with an engineering background and without lengthy ties to the company. Whether that is enough for lawmakers scrutinizing Boeing's operations remains to be seen.\n\n\"Mr. Ortberg is a mechanical engineer. I hope that means he will ensure that his top message for everyone is building the best airplane means building the safest airplane in the world,\" said Rep Rick Larsen, top Democrat on the House Transportation Committee who represents a district in Washington State home to major Boeing operations.\n\nAnalysts and acquaintances described Ortberg as being a good listener, honest and willing to take decisive action. \"We believe during his leadership at Collins he was well liked by employees and direct reports and very personable,\" said Jefferies analyst Sheila Kahyaoglu in a note.\n\n\"This was while being a tough negotiator dealing with a diverse set of customers and suppliers and managing the complexity of its diverse customer base.\"", "source": {"uri": "investing.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Investing.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Financial_Services/Leasing_Services", "label": "dmoz/Business/Financial Services/Leasing Services", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://i-invdn-com.investing.com/trkd-images/LYNXMPEK6U0RR_M.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9771357", "eventUri": "eng-9771357", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-08", "textStart": 322, "textEnd": 328}, {"amb": false, "date": "-01-05", "textStart": 535, "textEnd": 544}], "sentiment": 0.1294117647058823, "wgt": 190, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8252544497", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:28:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:28:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:27:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.khaleejtimes.com/business/aviation/boeing-names-industry-veteran-ortberg-as-ceo-to-steer-turnaround", "title": "Boeing names industry veteran Ortberg as CEO to steer turnaround", "body": "Kelly Ortberg, 64, will start as Boeing's new president and CEO on August 8.\n\nBoeing on Wednesday named aerospace industry veteran Kelly Ortberg as its new president and CEO after a months-long search, tasking the former Rockwell Collins executive with the monumental job of turning around the struggling planemaker.\n\nOrtberg, 64, will start on August 8 and face a multitude of issues, including reviving jet production and rebuilding trust with regulators, the industry and the flying public. Shares rose 2.9 per cent before the bell.\n\nBoeing, one of two global planemakers, has been mired in a reputational and safety crisis after a January 5 mid-air panel blowout on an Alaska Airlines-operated MAX 9 jet carrying 171 passengers. It posted a $1.4 billion loss in the second quarter as it continues to burn cash.\n\nThe accident eventually led to the resignation of CEO Dave Calhoun and departure of the company's previous board president as regulators took aim at the safety culture that was already shaken by previous crashes in 2018 and 2019.\n\nShortly after the accident, the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) barred Boeing from expanding production of its cash-cow 737 MAX family of jets without estimating how long the limitation will last.\n\nThe US aviation regulator capped production to 38 jets per month, though Reuters has reported that Boeing has been producing jets during some weeks at a much lower level.\n\nThe regulator on February 28 gave Boeing 90 days to develop a comprehensive plan to address \"systemic quality-control issues\", which the company submitted in May.\n\nHowever, the FAA's administrator has said Boeing would not be immediately allowed to increase 737 MAX production.\n\n\"During his leadership at Collins he was well liked by employees and direct reports and very personable,\" Jefferies analysts said in a note from earlier this week, after industry publication the Air Current reported Ortberg was a serious contender.\n\nJefferies said he was a \"tough negotiator\" dealing with a diverse set of customers and suppliers.\n\nA mechanical engineer, Ortberg has more than 30 years of experience in aerospace and defence, including numerous executive roles. After five years leading Rockwell Collins, he steered the company's integration with United Technologies and RTX until his retirement from RTX in 2021.\n\nBoeing CFO Brian West said in May the planemaker will burn rather than generate cash in 2024, hamstrung by lower jet deliveries compared to last year.", "source": {"uri": "khaleejtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Khaleej times"}, {"uri": "8252736461", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:33:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:33:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:32:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.aol.com/news/boeing-boss-kelly-ortberg-brings-150354412.html", "title": "New Boeing boss Kelly Ortberg brings engineering background, aerospace roots", "body": "New Boeing boss Kelly Ortberg brings engineering background, aerospace rootsAllison LampertJuly 31, 2024 at 5:03 PM\n\nBy Allison Lampert\n\n(Reuters) - Kelly Ortberg, the former Rockwell Collins boss coming out of retirement to take the reins of Boeing, is known as an aerospace veteran with an engineering background that contrasts with the troubled planemaker's former leadership.\n\nOrtberg will have a lengthy to-do list when he starts on Aug. 8. He'll have to strengthen relations between Boeing and the airlines that are its biggest customers, and earn trust with the regulators and lawmakers that have put the company under a microscope following a January 5 mid-air panel blowout that turned into a full-blown safety crisis.\n\nOrtberg has a background that threads a delicate needle. He's a company outsider but an industry insider, which industry officials said positions him as able to change the company's culture without upending its aerospace roots.\n\nBut questions remained about whether he would drive radical change favored by some politicians and industry analysts.\n\nBob Jordan, CEO of Southwest Airlines said the company looks forward \"to working with Kelly Ortberg in his efforts to return Boeing to its place as the leading American aerospace company.\"\n\nOrtberg became CEO of key aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins in 2013 and steered the company's integration with United Technologies and RTX until his retirement in 2021. He also served as chair of the U.S. aerospace advocacy group Aerospace Industries Association (AIA) during the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\n\"This is as clear a break from the past as you can imagine,\" said Richard Aboulafia, analyst at consultancy AeroDynamic Advisory.\n\nIndustry insiders had previously hoped Boeing would hire someone on the younger side, in the expectation that it will take years to turn the company around. Ortberg is 64, however, and Boeing said it waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 just like it did for CEO Dave Calhoun, who is departing after a management shakeup earlier this year.\n\nAeroDynamic Advisory analyst Kevin Michaels, who first met Ortberg at Rockwell Collins in 1996, said Ortberg is young-looking and energetic and he didn't see his age as a barrier for the top job.\n\n\"We all thought that he retired too young,\" Michaels said.\n\nOrtberg is said to have beaten out Boeing Commercial Airplanes CEO Stephanie Pope and Spirit AeroSystems boss and former Boeing executive Pat Shanahan for the job.\n\n\"I think it's a positive,\" said one portfolio manager that holds Boeing stock. \"The narrative had been, 'I can't believe only Boeing insiders wanted this job.'\"\n\nBoeing had faced pressure from industry executives and U.S. lawmakers to choose new leadership with an engineering background and without lengthy ties to the company. Whether that is enough for lawmakers scrutinizing Boeing's operations remains to be seen.\n\n\"Mr. Ortberg is a mechanical engineer. I hope that means he will ensure that his top message for everyone is building the best airplane means building the safest airplane in the world,\" said Rep Rick Larsen, top Democrat on the House Transportation Committee who represents a district in Washington State home to major Boeing operations.\n\nAnalysts and acquaintances described Ortberg as being a good listener, honest and willing to take decisive action. \"We believe during his leadership at Collins he was well liked by employees and direct reports and very personable,\" said Jefferies analyst Sheila Kahyaoglu in a note.\n\n\"This was while being a tough negotiator dealing with a diverse set of customers and suppliers and managing the complexity of its diverse customer base.\"\n\n(Reporting By Allison Lampert in Montreal. Additional reporting by Tim Hepher in Paris, Rajesh Kumar Singh in Chicago and David Shepardson in Washington. {"uri": "8252639558", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:30:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:30:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:28:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/07/31/business/boeing-taps-kelly-ortberg-as-new-ceo-after-mid-air-blowout-fiasco/", "title": "Boeing taps Kelly Ortberg as CEO following safety crises, including...", "body": "Boeing announced Wednesday it has tapped Robert \"Kelly\" Ortberg to replace outgoing CEO Dave Calhoun following a months-long search as the plane manufacturer struggles to bounce back from several safety crises -- including the mid-air blowout of a door panel.\n\nOrtberg, a longtime aerospace industry veteran, faces a multitude of issues, including reviving jet production and rebuilding trust with regulators, the industry and the public. He will start on Aug. 8.\n\nThe 64-year-old Ortberg previously led aviation company Rockwell Collins -- which became Collins Aerospace in 2018 and is now a part of RTX.\n\n\\He retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nOrtberg will take the reins and join the company board as Boeing faces a host of reputation and monetary challenges, which escalated early this year after a door plug flew off an Alaska Airlines Boeing plane in mid-air.\n\nAt the time, Boeing was already taking heat over two fatal 737 MAX plane crashes.\n\nThe company announced in March that Calhoun would leave his position by the end of the year.\n\nThe company said it was also replacing its then-chairman and its head of commercial aircraft.\n\nNow, Ortberg is tasked with boosting the planemaker's image and turning around earnings.\n\n\"The Board conducted a thorough and extensive search process over the last several months to select the next CEO of Boeing and Kelly has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter,\" Chairman Steven Mollenkopf said in a note to employees on Wednesday.\n\n\"Kelly is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies,\" Mollenkopf said.\n\nBoeing's new CEO announcement comes alongside its disappointing second-quarter earnings, which saw bigger losses and weaker revenue than expected.\n\nThe aircraft manufacturer reported a loss of $2.90 per share adjusted -- nearly $1 below expectations that it would lose $1.97 per share adjusted, according to LSEG analysts.\n\nRevenue tumbled 15% to $16.87 billion, below expectations of $17.23 billion, according to LSEG analysts.\n\nMeanwhile, Boeing is facing heightened regulatory scrutiny after its door plug scandal and fatal plane crashes.\n\nSenators grilled Calhoun in June, questioning why he hadn't immediately resigned.\n\nCalhoun acknowledged the door plug scandal was the result of a manufacturing defect.\n\nBoeing also took responsibility for the development of key software linked to the 2018 and 2019 fatal crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia, which killed a combined 346 people.\n\nMost recently, Boeing agreed to plead guilty to a criminal fraud conspiracy charge and pay a $243.6 million fine after it breached a 2021 prosecution agreement connected to the fatal crashes, according to a court filing.\n\nCustomers are also turning against the manufacturer, concerned with plane safety and frustrated with long flight delays at airports nationwide.\n\nBoeing is not safe from internal struggles, either, as its largest union threatened to strike if contract negotiations don't end up in union members' favor.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8252583057", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:53:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:53:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:53:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2024/0731/1462859-boeing-names-new-ceo/", "title": "Boeing names aerospace veteran Kelly Ortberg as new CEO", "body": "Boeing has today named aerospace industry veteran Kelly Ortberg as its new President and CEO after a months-long search, tasking the former Rockwell Collins executive with the monumental job of turning around the struggling planemaker.\n\nOrtberg, 64, will start on August 8 and face a multitude of issues, including reviving jet production and rebuilding trust with regulators, the industry and the flying public.\n\nBoeing, one of two global planemakers, has been mired in a reputational and safety crisis after a January 5 mid-air panel blowout on an Alaska Airlines-operated MAX 9 jet carrying 171 passengers. It posted a $1.4 billion loss in the second quarter as it continues to burn cash.\n\nThe accident eventually led to the resignation of CEO Dave Calhoun and departure of the company's previous board president as regulators took aim at the safety culture that was already shaken by previous crashes in 2018 and 2019.\n\nShortly after the accident, the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) barred Boeing from expanding production of its cash-cow 737 MAX family of jets without estimating how long the limitation will last.\n\nThe US aviation regulator capped production to 38 jets per month, though Reuters has reported that Boeing has been producing jets during some weeks at a much lower level.\n\nThe regulator on February 28 gave Boeing 90 days to develop a comprehensive plan to address \"systemic quality-control issues\", which the company submitted in May.\n\nHowever, the FAA's administrator has said Boeing would not be immediately allowed to increase 737 MAX production.\n\n\"During his leadership at Collins he was well liked by employees and direct reports and very personable,\" Jefferies analysts said in a note from earlier this week, after industry publication the Air Current reported Ortberg was a serious contender.\n\nJefferies said he was a \"tough negotiator\" dealing with a diverse set of customers and suppliers.\n\nA mechanical engineer, Ortberg has more than 30 years of experience in aerospace and defence, including numerous executive roles. After five years leading Rockwell Collins, he steered the company's integration with United Technologies and RTX until his retirement from RTX in 2021.\n\nHe pipped Patrick Shanahan to one of the top industrial jobs after the former Spirit Aero CEO was seen as a favourite to succeed Calhoun by some analysts and investors.\n\n\"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started,\" Ortberg said in a statement.\n\nDuring the second quarter, Boeing said it delivered a total of 92 aircraft, down 32% from last year. It posted a loss of $2.33 a share, as its troubled defence and space business exacerbated the financial strain on the company.\n\nThe Defense, Space and Security unit, one of Boeing's three main businesses, has lost billions of dollars in 2023 and 2022, which executives attributed to cost overruns on fixed-price contracts.\n\nSuch contracts have high margins but leave defence contractors vulnerable to inflationary pressures that have dented US corporate earnings in the last few years.\n\nThe planemaker used to bid aggressively for fixed-price contracts before the pandemic, but has now said it would pivot away from such contracts to stem losses at the business, which amounted to $1.76 billion last year.\n\nAhead of last week's Farnborough Air Show, the unit's head had said it was \"significantly challenged\" during the quarter.\n\nBoeing CFO Brian West said in May the planemaker will burn rather than generate cash in 2024, hamstrung by lower jet deliveries compared to last {"uri": "8249247212", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "16:23:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T16:23:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T16:22:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://qz.com/boeing-ceo-search-kelly-ortberg-1851607626", "title": "The Boeing CEO search just roped in a big aerospace name", "body": "A new name is swirling around as a possible CEO for Boeing. The aerospace industry publication The Air Current reported Sunday that former Rockwell Collins CEO Kelly Ortberg is being considered as a replacement for outgoing Boeing head Dave Calhoun.\n\nThe planemaker is in search of a new leader after one of its 737 Max 9 jets suffered a door plug blowout in January. Since then, the company lost all the momentum from its hoped-for comeback after its last 737 Max mess. Calhoun is retiring at the end of the year.\n\nAs Rockwell Collins CEO, Ortberg led a major supplier of flight controls and in-flight entertainment systems. When aviation air conditioning supplier United Technologies Corporation bought Rockwell Collins in 2018, he stayed on to run the division. After RTX Corporation -- the parent company of defense giant Raytheon -- merged with UTC in 2020, Ortberg served for a brief time as a \"special adviser\" to RTX's CEO.\n\nOrtberg joins a list of other names reportedly being considered for the top Boeing job.\n\nAmong them is longtime Boeing executive Stephanie Pope, currently the head of Boeing's commercial airliner division and before that the company's chief commercial officer. The industry publication Aviation Week reported last month that a poll of the aerospace industry suppliers revealed that 30% of them expect her to be named CEO.\n\nAnother name is Pat Shanahan, the CEO of Spirit Aerosystems. Spirit builds fuselages and was a former Boeing subsidiary that was spun out in 2005 and reacquired earlier this month for $8.3 billion. It built the faulty fuselage that suffered the blowout, but Shanahan still demurred when he was asked about taking over Boeing -- getting the reintegration right will be key to restarting the 737 Max moneymaking machine when the Federal Aviation Administration gives the green light for faster production speeds.\n\nThe Air Current suggests that a decision on the new CEO could come as soon as this {"uri": "2024-07-439654697", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:27:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:27:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:21:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.wfxg.com/news/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-reports-hefty-loss/article_5a454492-5bef-5fbd-9889-2865966bb884.html", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it reports hefty loss", "body": "Boeing is at work on the certification of the new 777X in Everett, Washington\n\nBoeing named former Rockwell Collins chief Robert \"Kelly\" Ortberg its next CEO Wednesday, as the aviation giant reported a hefty loss on continued operational problems.\n\nOrtberg, 64, helped lead Rockwell Collins and integrate it into United Technology prior to his retirement from RTX in 2021.\n\nHis appointment, which will take effect August 8, comes as Boeing attempts to rebound from a series of safety and quality control problems that have sharpened scrutiny on the company.\n\nThose difficulties were immediately visible in Boeing's second-quarter results released Wednesday, a loss of $1.4 billion, compared with a loss of $149 million in the year-ago period.\n\nRevenues fell 14.6 percent to $16.9 billion.\n\nThe quarterly results reflected a continued drag from Boeing's commercial division, where it has lowered production while upgrading safety and quality control practices under the close watch of regulators.\n\nThe latest results also showed significant weakness in its defense business due to a number of fixed price contracts where it has experienced deep losses due to supply chain problems, as well as higher engineering costs and technical issues.\n\nBoeing's press release listed four defense contracts behind an operating loss of $913 million in the quarter.\n\n- Leadership shakeup -\n\nBoeing has been in the hot seat since a January incident in which a 737 MAX operated by Alaska Airlines made an emergency landing after a fuselage panel blew out mid-flight.\n\nCurrent leader Dave Calhoun ascended to CEO in January 2020 unexpectedly following the ouster of predecessor Dennis Muilenburg amid fallout from the MAX crashes.\n\nCalhoun appeared poised to stay CEO to 2028 until the January 2024 Alaska Airlines incident sparked outrage on Capitol Hill and concern among Boeing's airline customers, whose reported efforts to engage the board preceded Calhoun's announcement on March 25 that he would step down by the end of 2024.\n\nSome names mentioned as CEO candidates such as GE Aerospace CEO Larry Culp and Spirit AeroSystems CEO Patrick Shanahan took themselves out of consideration.\n\nAt Boeing's annual meeting in May, Chairman Steve Mollenkopf vowed to find the \"right\" person to \"regain the trust lost in recent times to get back on track.\"\n\nAviation experts have said the next Boeing CEO should ideally have an aerospace background, experience managing big manufacturing projects, strategic smarts and a hands-on approach to safety.\n\nSome have emphasized the need for an engineering background. Communications skills are also critical, in part to be able to navigate congressional hearings and other politically-oriented venues.\n\nIn Wednesday's press release, Mollenkopf described Ortberg as \"an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry,\" according to a message to employees.\n\nOrtberg said \"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" according to the press release. \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nRepresentative Rick Larsen, the senior Democrat on a key House Transportation Committee, said on X that was \"encouraged\" by the appointment.\n\n\"Mr. Ortberg is a mechanical engineer,\" Larsen said. \"I hope that means he will ensure that his top message for everyone is building the best airplane means building the safest airplane in the world.\"\n\nOrtberg is set to take office on August 8, just after a two-day hearing organized by the National Transportation Safety Board in Washington on the Alaska Airlines incident.\n\nThe Alaska Airlines incident raised fresh scrutiny on Boeing and the MAX following two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019 that led to a lengthy grounding of the plane.\n\nBoeing agreed to plead guilty to a fraud charge in connection with the MAX certification as part of a plea deal with the Department of Justice, US officials announced July 24.\n\nShares of Boeing rose 1.6 percent in pre-market trading.\n\njmb/sms", "source": {"uri": "wfxg.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WFXG FOX54"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [], "categories": [], The 64-year-old industry veteran will lead Boeing through a \"consequential period\" in the aerospace giant's history, Mollenkopf noted.\n\n\"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront,\" Ortberg said in a statement. \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nBoeing's year has gone from bad to worse after a door plug blew out mid-flight on a Boeing 737 Max 9 plane in January. The Arlington, Virginia-based aircraft maker was hit with a barrage of regulatory scrutiny and complaints from multiple whistleblowers over the safety of its planes.\n\nOutgoing CEO Calhoun defended the company's safety culture on Capitol Hill last month, telling the Senate investigations subcommittee in a hearing that despite its problems, Boeing is making progress toward improving its quality {"uri": "8252524100", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:16:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:16:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:15:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://aviationweek.com/air-transport/aircraft-propulsion/boeing-names-kelly-ortberg-next-ceo-president", "title": "Boeing Names Kelly Ortberg As Next CEO and President | Aviation Week Network", "body": "Boeing has named Kelly Ortberg to be its new CEO and President from Aug. 8, taking on the massive challenge of reviving the aerospace giant.\n\nOrtberg, a respected former Rockwell Collins leader who was a key force behind the melt-up and formation of industry giant RTX, replaces Dave Calhoun, who had previously announced his plans to leave the company by year-end.\n\n\"Kelly is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies,\" Boeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf said July 31 as he announced the change.\n\nOrtberg, 64, also will join the Boeing board.\n\nMollenkopf thanked Calhoun, who will remain a special adviser to the board until March 2025, according to a Boeing statement.\n\n\"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" Ortberg said in the statement. \"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront. There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nOrtberg holds a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering from the University of Iowa. His career started in 1983 as an engineer at Texas Instruments. He then joined Rockwell Collins in 1987 as a program manager and was promoted several times prior to becoming its president and CEO in 2013.\n\nAfter taking the corner office at what was a key avionics supplier, Ortberg began a long march of massive mergers and acquisitions that both redrew the industrial landscape in aerospace, and helped propel Rockwell from a niche supplier to a key Tier 1. Ortberg drove Rockwell's acquisition of flight-services provider Arinc for $1.4 billion and cabin interiors provider B/E Aerospace for $8.3 billion, until unveiling Rockwell's own 2018 merger with United Technologies for $30 billion. Rockwell was combined with then-UTC Aerospace Systems to form the Collins Aerospace division. In April 2020, parent United Technologies merged with large defense prime Raytheon to form Raytheon Technologies, later renamed RTX.\n\nUnder Ortberg's tenure, Rockwell expanded at a 14% compound annual growth rate, from $4 billion in 2013 revs to $9 billion when it was sold to United Technologies, according to Jefferies analysts.\n\nOrtberg quietly served then-RTX Chairman and CEO Greg Hayes until Ortberg retired from executives in March 2021. His absence was noted by several observers in the industry who wondered how the aerospace industry could let someone as respected and proven slip away. His name would periodically surface when CEO searches were known to be occurring at various companies, and indeed, his name was floated as a potential Boeing CEO before Calhoun was appointed in January 2020.\n\nAnalysts see the logic in Ortberg's appointment now.\n\n\"We believe during his leadership at Collins he was well liked by employees and direct reports and very personable,\" said the Jefferies team, led by Sheila Kahyaoglu. \"This was while being a tough negotiator dealing with a diverse set of customers and suppliers and managing the complexity of its diverse customer base, which included negotiating through Boeing's Partnering for Success.\" Ortberg also clearly has experience with major acquisitions and corporate restructuring.\n\n\"There is some credence to bringing in an outsider who has a strong working knowledge of Boeing, but no direct current tie,\" the analysts continued. \"This fresh start includes ensuring a healthy supply chain, while ensuring a content employee base and navigating the current union negotiation.\"\n\nOrtberg has bested a short list of other candidates who were widely talked about as contenders for the top Boeing job, including current COO Stephanie Pope, current Spirit CEO Pat Shanahan, and others. Pope was believed to be Calhoun's personal choice as she was appointed companywide COO at the start of this year, and in the spring took over Boeing Commercial Airplanes from Stan Deal. No immediate word was provided about the executive structure moving forward.", "source": {"uri": "aviationweek.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aviation Week"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8252694809", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:06:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:06:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:04:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/entertainment/3037292-veteran-kelly-ortberg-returns-from-retirement-to-lead-boeing-amidst-turbulent-times", "title": "Veteran Kelly Ortberg Returns from Retirement to Lead Boeing Amidst Turbulent Times | Entertainment", "body": "Kelly Ortberg, the former Rockwell Collins boss coming out of retirement to take the reins of Boeing, is known as an aerospace veteran with an engineering background that contrasts with the troubled planemaker's former leadership.\n\nOrtberg will have a lengthy to-do list when he starts on Aug. 8. He'll have to strengthen relations between Boeing and the airlines that are its biggest customers, and earn trust with the regulators and lawmakers that have put the company under a microscope following a January 5 mid-air panel blowout that turned into a full-blown safety crisis. Ortberg has a background that threads a delicate needle. He's a company outsider but an industry insider, which industry officials said positions him as able to change the company's culture without upending its aerospace roots.\n\nBut questions remained about whether he would drive radical change favored by some politicians and industry analysts. Bob Jordan, CEO of Southwest Airlines said the company looks forward \"to working with Kelly Ortberg in his efforts to return Boeing to its place as the leading American aerospace company.\"\n\nOrtberg became CEO of key aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins in 2013 and steered the company's integration with United Technologies and RTX until his retirement in 2021. He also served as chair of the U.S. aerospace advocacy group Aerospace Industries Association (AIA) during the COVID-19 pandemic. \"This is as clear a break from the past as you can imagine,\" said Richard Aboulafia, analyst at consultancy AeroDynamic Advisory. Industry insiders had previously hoped Boeing would hire someone on the younger side, in the expectation that it will take years to turn the company around. Ortberg is 64, however, and Boeing said it waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 just like it did for CEO Dave Calhoun, who is departing after a management shakeup earlier this year. AeroDynamic Advisory analyst Kevin Michaels, who first met Ortberg at Rockwell Collins in 1996, said Ortberg is young-looking and energetic and he didn't see his age as a barrier for the top job. \"We all thought that he retired too young,\" Michaels said. Ortberg is said to have beaten out Boeing Commercial Airplanes CEO Stephanie Pope and Spirit AeroSystems boss and former Boeing executive Pat Shanahan for the job.\n\n\"I think it's a positive,\" said one portfolio manager that holds Boeing stock. \"The narrative had been, 'I can't believe only Boeing insiders wanted this job.'\" Boeing had faced pressure from industry executives and U.S. lawmakers to choose new leadership with an engineering background and without lengthy ties to the company. Whether that is enough for lawmakers scrutinizing Boeing's operations remains to be seen.\n\n\"Mr. Ortberg is a mechanical engineer. I hope that means he will ensure that his top message for everyone is building the best airplane means building the safest airplane in the world,\" said Rep Rick Larsen, top Democrat on the House Transportation Committee who represents a district in Washington State home to major Boeing operations. Analysts and acquaintances described Ortberg as being a good listener, honest and willing to take decisive action. \"We believe during his leadership at Collins he was well liked by employees and direct reports and very personable,\" said Jefferies analyst Sheila Kahyaoglu in a note.\n\n\"This was while being a tough negotiator dealing with a diverse set of customers and suppliers and managing the complexity of its diverse customer base.\"\n\n(Reporting By Allison Lampert in Montreal. Additional reporting by Tim Hepher in Paris, Rajesh Kumar Singh in Chicago and David Shepardson in Washington. {"uri": "2024-07-439556587", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:01:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:01:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:58:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.aol.com/boeing-q2-earnings-preview-investors-174003462.html", "title": "Boeing taps Kelly Ortberg as new CEO, reports wider-than-expected Q2 loss and revenue miss", "body": "Boeing (BA) on Wednesday named former Rockwell Collins CEO Kelly Ortberg its new president and CEO, replacing outgoing head Dave Calhoun. The troubled airplane-maker also reported a wider-than-expected second quarter loss and revenue miss.\n\n\"The Board conducted a thorough and extensive search process over the last several months to select the next CEO of Boeing and Kelly has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter,\" said Boeing chairman Steven Mollenkopf in a statement.\n\nOrtberg will start Aug. 8 and has been named to the Boeing board.\n\nHe will inherit an aerospace giant that has faced an extraordinarily turbulent year, which was reflected in its second-quarter earnings report. Boeing reported revenue of $16.9 billion vs. $17.46 billion estimated per Bloomberg. The company also posted an adjusted loss per share of $2.90 vs. $1.82 estimated, resulting in a core operating loss of $1.392 billion.\n\nFree-cash flow burn hit $4.3 billion, topping the nearly $4 billion it did lost in Q1, meaning the company could reported an astounding $8.256 billion in negative free cash flow for the first half of the year.\n\nBoeing stock was up about 3% in pre-market trading. The stock is down over 25% this year.\n\nNot surprisingly, Boeing's commercial deliveries took a hit in the second quarter as well. Boeing delivered 92 commercial jets in Q2, down from the 136 planes delivered year ago, or a 32% drop. The 737 Max program had 70 deliveries in Q2, down from the 103 delivered a year ago.\n\nBefore its recent issues, Boeing had monthly production target of 38 737 MAX jets, with a stretch goal of 50 planes per month. Boeing confirmed that it intends to hit the 38 plane goal by the end of the year.\n\nBoeing also delivered nine widebody Dreamliner jets in Q2, down from 20 a year ago. The Dreamliner jet has been the subject of a few whistleblower complaints in 2024 alone, highlighting more issues with Boeing's production and assembly processes. Boeing said it plans to return to 5 787 produced per month\n\nBoeing pulled its full-year outlook at the start of the year given the issues it was facing, most seriously at the time the Alaska Airlines door plug blowout in January.\n\n\"Despite a challenging quarter, we are making substantial progress strengthening our quality management system and positioning our company for the future,\" said Dave Calhoun, outgoing Boeing president and CEO.\n\nHe added: \"We are executing on our comprehensive safety and quality plan and have reached an agreement to acquire Spirit AeroSystems. While we have more work ahead, the steps we're taking will help stabilize our operations and ensure Boeing is the company the world needs it to be. We are making important progress in our recovery and will continue to build trust through action and transparency.\"\n\nBoeing also pleaded guilty last week to a criminal fraud conspiracy charge and agreed to pay at least $243.6 million after breaching a 2021 consent decree with the Department of Justice, with the government alleging Boeing continued risky procedures in plane construction and didn't keep accurate records following the two 737 MAX crashes in 2019 and 2020.\n\nFamilies of the victims of the two 737 MAX crashes, who have been vocal about Boeing getting off too lightly given the seriousness of the charges, are challenging the Boeing's plea deal and have filed a motion to oppose it -- meaning Boeing isn't out of the legal jeopardy, yet.\n\nPras Subramanian is a reporter for Yahoo Finance covering the auto industry. {"uri": "2024-07-439554521", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:59:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:59:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:44:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-a-loss-of-more-than-1-4-billion/article_34fe275e-6121-5d31-ba5d-884418006e14.html", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts a loss of more than $1.4 billion in second quarter", "body": "By DAVID KOENIG - AP Airlines Writer\n\nBoeing named a longtime aerospace industry veteran as its next chief executive, who will take over a company that has been rocked by legal, regulatory and production problems.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, 64, a former CEO at aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun, 67, as CEO effective Aug. 8, the company said on Wednesday.\n\nBoeing announced its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the Max, two of which crashed, killing 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration has increased its oversight of the company following mistakes including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet. It is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nValparaiso University to eliminate 30 academic programs Davich: 'Mr. Safety' killed at dangerous bike trail intersection in Region Pierogi Fest grew from one vendor who sold out in an hour to a wall-to-wall crush of starch-seeking revelers, expects record attendance Former U.S. Steel South Works site to be transformed into quantum computing park UPDATE: Valpo woman identified as deceased in fatal U.S. 20 crash Mind on Money: xxxxx BIZ TEMPLATE (copy) Police seek help identifying 2 captured on video following home invasion 24-Hour Pierogi People: Annual Whiting festival elevates the dumpling to an artform Big Lots closing stores in Chicagoland and Indiana, warns it may close all stores Davich: Frankly, this is the best hot dog joint in the Region Pastor seeks to dump video of him allegedly battering child NWI Business Ins and Outs: Cajun Express, Fuerte Restaurant, Frankie's Philly Steak, The Waxi Taxi, Phenix Salon Suites and Boot Barn opening Man charged with operating bar in LaPorte home Boy taken to hospital after being struck by vehicle in Porter County, police say Former Lake tourism chief denies defrauding group of $400K, federal filing says\n\nThe company is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nOrtberg will become CEO and president on Aug. 8, Boeing said. He emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial-airplanes division.\n\nChairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\"\n\nMollenkopf said Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nA Boeing spokesperson said the company had waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, reported a loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier.\n\nExcluding special items, the loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion.\n\nThe commercial-airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines -- 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA has limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners since shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine that it would pay as part of an agreement with the Justice Department to plead guilty to fraud in connection with development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the deal, which is opposed by many families of those who died in the two Max crashes.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. The smaller services business earned $870 million.\n\nBoeing shares added 2% in premarket trading.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. Ortberg, a seasoned aerospace executive, steps in following the fallout from a January incident and subsequent financial woes, including a significant quarterly loss and stagnant jet production.\n\nBoeing has named aerospace industry veteran Kelly Ortberg as its new President and CEO, effectively tasking him with the monumental challenge of revitalizing the struggling planemaker. Ortberg, who previously served as a top executive at Rockwell Collins, will assume his role on August 8. He will face the daunting task of not only reviving jet production but also rebuilding trust with regulators and the public.\n\nThe announcement comes after a troubling period for Boeing, one of two global planemaking giants. The company has been grappling with a reputational and safety crisis, highlighted by a January 5 mid-air panel blowout on an Alaska Airlines-operated MAX 9 jet carrying 171 passengers. The incident resulted in the resignation of CEO Dave Calhoun and the departure of the company's previous board president. Further compounding the issue, Boeing reported a $1.4 billion loss for the quarter, exacerbated by ongoing cash flow problems.\n\nIn response to the January incident, the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) placed a cap on Boeing's production of its 737 MAX jets at 38 units per month. Despite this, Boeing has been producing at lower levels during some weeks. The FAA has mandated that the company develop a comprehensive plan to address systemic quality-control issues, which was submitted in May. However, Boeing is still not permitted to increase 737 MAX production immediately. The company delivered only 92 aircraft in the second quarter, a 32% drop compared to last year, which further strained its finances. {"uri": "8252640564", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:30:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:30:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:28:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-reports-hefty-loss/article_ba4dc736-d575-57e5-8113-ba6421332080.html", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it reports hefty loss", "body": "Boeing is at work on the certification of the new 777X in Everett, Washington\n\nBoeing named former Rockwell Collins chief Robert \"Kelly\" Ortberg its next CEO Wednesday, as the aviation giant reported a hefty loss on continued operational problems.\n\nOrtberg, 64, helped lead Rockwell Collins and integrate it into United Technology prior to his retirement from RTX in 2021.\n\nHis appointment, which will take effect August 8, comes as Boeing attempts to rebound from a series of safety and quality control problems that have sharpened scrutiny on the company.\n\nThose difficulties were immediately visible in Boeing's second-quarter results released Wednesday, a loss of $1.4 billion, compared with a loss of $149 million in the year-ago period.\n\nRevenues fell 14.6 percent to $16.9 billion.\n\nThe quarterly results reflected a continued drag from Boeing's commercial division, where it has lowered production while upgrading safety and quality control practices under the close watch of regulators.\n\nThe latest results also showed significant weakness in its defense business due to a number of fixed price contracts where it has experienced deep losses due to supply chain problems, as well as higher engineering costs and technical issues.\n\nBoeing's press release listed four defense contracts behind an operating loss of $913 million in the quarter.\n\n- Leadership shakeup -\n\nBoeing has been in the hot seat since a January incident in which a 737 MAX operated by Alaska Airlines made an emergency landing after a fuselage panel blew out mid-flight.\n\nCurrent leader Dave Calhoun ascended to CEO in January 2020 unexpectedly following the ouster of predecessor Dennis Muilenburg amid fallout from the MAX crashes.\n\nCalhoun appeared poised to stay CEO to 2028 until the January 2024 Alaska Airlines incident sparked outrage on Capitol Hill and concern among Boeing's airline customers, whose reported efforts to engage the board preceded Calhoun's announcement on March 25 that he would step down by the end of 2024.\n\nSome names mentioned as CEO candidates such as GE Aerospace CEO Larry Culp and Spirit AeroSystems CEO Patrick Shanahan took themselves out of consideration.\n\nMore from this section Haverstraw police arrest suspect in July shooting, tracking him to South Carolina USDA Toughens Rules on Salmonella in Poultry HSBC records $21.6 billion pre-tax profit in first half 2024\n\nAt Boeing's annual meeting in May, Chairman Steve Mollenkopf vowed to find the \"right\" person to \"regain the trust lost in recent times to get back on track.\"\n\nAviation experts have said the next Boeing CEO should ideally have an aerospace background, experience managing big manufacturing projects, strategic smarts and a hands-on approach to safety.\n\nSome have emphasized the need for an engineering background. Communications skills are also critical, in part to be able to navigate congressional hearings and other politically-oriented venues.\n\nIn Wednesday's press release, Mollenkopf described Ortberg as \"an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry,\" according to a message to employees.\n\nOrtberg said \"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" according to the press release. \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nRepresentative Rick Larsen, the senior Democrat on a key House Transportation Committee, said on X that was \"encouraged\" by the appointment.\n\n\"Mr. Ortberg is a mechanical engineer,\" Larsen said. \"I hope that means he will ensure that his top message for everyone is building the best airplane means building the safest airplane in the world.\"\n\nOrtberg is set to take office on August 8, just after a two-day hearing organized by the National Transportation Safety Board in Washington on the Alaska Airlines incident.\n\nThe Alaska Airlines incident raised fresh scrutiny on Boeing and the MAX following two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019 that led to a lengthy grounding of the plane.\n\nBoeing agreed to plead guilty to a fraud charge in connection with the MAX certification as part of a plea deal with the Department of Justice, US officials announced July 24.\n\nShares of Boeing rose 1.6 percent in pre-market trading.\n\njmb/sms", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8252473590", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:45:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:45:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:45:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/boeing-names-aerospace-veteran-kelly-ortberg-ceo-to-steer-turnaround/article_6f899407-da40-5260-9ed7-86f1aea27ff5.html", "title": "Boeing names aerospace veteran Kelly Ortberg CEO to steer turnaround", "body": "By Abhijith Ganapavaram and Allison Lampert\n\n(Reuters) -Boeing on Wednesday named aerospace industry veteran Kelly Ortberg as its new President and CEO after a months-long search, tasking the former Rockwell Collins executive with the monumental job of turning around the struggling planemaker.\n\nOrtberg, 64, will start on Aug. 8 and face a multitude of issues, including reviving jet production and rebuilding trust with regulators, the industry and the flying public. Shares rose 2.9% before the bell.\n\nBoeing, one of two global planemakers, has been mired in a reputational and safety crisis after a Jan. 5 mid-air panel blowout on an Alaska Airlines-operated MAX 9 jet carrying 171 passengers. It posted a $1.4 billion loss in the second quarter as it continues to burn cash.\n\nThe accident eventually led to the resignation of CEO Dave Calhoun and departure of the company's previous board president as regulators took aim at the safety culture that was already shaken by previous crashes in 2018 and 2019.\n\nShortly after the accident, the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) barred Boeing from expanding production of its cash-cow 737 MAX family of jets without estimating how long the limitation will last.\n\nThe U.S. aviation regulator capped production to 38 jets per month, though Reuters has reported that Boeing has been producing jets during some weeks at a much lower level.\n\nThe regulator on Feb. 28 gave Boeing 90 days to develop a comprehensive plan to address \"systemic quality-control issues\", which the company submitted in May.\n\nHowever, the FAA's administrator has said Boeing would not be immediately allowed to increase 737 MAX production.\n\nANALYSTS CHEER APPOINTMENT\n\n\"During his leadership at Collins he was well liked by employees and direct reports and very personable,\" Jefferies analysts said in a note from earlier this week, after industry publication the Air Current reported Ortberg was a serious contender.\n\nJefferies said he was a \"tough negotiator\" dealing with a diverse set of customers and suppliers.\n\nA mechanical engineer, Ortberg has more than 30 years of experience in aerospace and defense, including numerous executive roles. After five years leading Rockwell Collins, he steered the company's integration with United Technologies and RTX until his retirement from RTX in 2021.\n\nHe pipped Patrick Shanahan to one of the top industrial jobs after the former Spirit Aero CEO was seen as a favorite to succeed Calhoun by some analysts and investors.\n\n\"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started,\" Ortberg said in a statement.\n\nDEFEENCE BUSINESS STRUGGLES\n\nDuring the second quarter, Boeing delivered a total of 92 aircraft, down 32% from last year. It posted a loss of $2.33 a share, as its troubled defense and space business exacerbated the financial strain on the company.\n\nThe Defense, Space and Security unit, one of Boeing's three main businesses, has lost billions of dollars in 2023 and 2022, which executives attributed to cost overruns on fixed-price contracts.\n\nSuch contracts have high margins but leave defense contractors vulnerable to inflationary pressures that have dented U.S. corporate earnings in the last few years.\n\nThe planemaker used to bid aggressively for fixed-price contracts before the pandemic, but has now said it would pivot away from such contracts to stem losses at the business, which amounted to $1.76 billion last year.\n\nAhead of last week's Farnborough Air Show, the unit's head had said it was \"significantly challenged\" during the quarter.\n\nBoeing CFO Brian West said in May the planemaker will burn rather than generate cash in 2024, hamstrung by lower jet deliveries compared to last year.\n\n(Reporting by Abhijith Ganapavaram in Bengaluru; Editing by Arun Koyyur)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Colorado Springs Gazette"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Aviation_Administration", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Federal Aviation Administration"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_executive_officer", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Chief executive officer"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rockwell_Collins", "type": {"uri": "2024-07-439652880", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:25:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:25:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:21:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-reports-hefty-loss/article_b721d051-0072-526c-a133-797aa1c2702e.html", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it reports hefty loss", "body": "Boeing is at work on the certification of the new 777X in Everett, Washington\n\nBoeing named former Rockwell Collins chief Robert \"Kelly\" Ortberg its next CEO Wednesday, as the aviation giant reported a hefty loss on continued operational problems.\n\nOrtberg, 64, helped lead Rockwell Collins and integrate it into United Technology prior to his retirement from RTX in 2021.\n\nHis appointment, which will take effect August 8, comes as Boeing attempts to rebound from a series of safety and quality control problems that have sharpened scrutiny on the company.\n\nThose difficulties were immediately visible in Boeing's second-quarter results released Wednesday, a loss of $1.4 billion, compared with a loss of $149 million in the year-ago period.\n\nRevenues fell 14.6 percent to $16.9 billion.\n\nThe quarterly results reflected a continued drag from Boeing's commercial division, where it has lowered production while upgrading safety and quality control practices under the close watch of regulators.\n\nThe latest results also showed significant weakness in its defense business due to a number of fixed price contracts where it has experienced deep losses due to supply chain problems, as well as higher engineering costs and technical issues.\n\nBoeing's press release listed four defense contracts behind an operating loss of $913 million in the quarter.\n\n- Leadership shakeup -\n\nBoeing has been in the hot seat since a January incident in which a 737 MAX operated by Alaska Airlines made an emergency landing after a fuselage panel blew out mid-flight.\n\nCurrent leader Dave Calhoun ascended to CEO in January 2020 unexpectedly following the ouster of predecessor Dennis Muilenburg amid fallout from the MAX crashes.\n\nCalhoun appeared poised to stay CEO to 2028 until the January 2024 Alaska Airlines incident sparked outrage on Capitol Hill and concern among Boeing's airline customers, whose reported efforts to engage the board preceded Calhoun's announcement on March 25 that he would step down by the end of 2024.\n\nSome names mentioned as CEO candidates such as GE Aerospace CEO Larry Culp and Spirit AeroSystems CEO Patrick Shanahan took themselves out of consideration.\n\nAt Boeing's annual meeting in May, Chairman Steve Mollenkopf vowed to find the \"right\" person to \"regain the trust lost in recent times to get back on track.\"\n\nAviation experts have said the next Boeing CEO should ideally have an aerospace background, experience managing big manufacturing projects, strategic smarts and a hands-on approach to safety.\n\nSome have emphasized the need for an engineering background. Communications skills are also critical, in part to be able to navigate congressional hearings and other politically-oriented venues.\n\nIn Wednesday's press release, Mollenkopf described Ortberg as \"an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry,\" according to a message to employees.\n\nOrtberg said \"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" according to the press release. \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nRepresentative Rick Larsen, the senior Democrat on a key House Transportation Committee, said on X that was \"encouraged\" by the appointment.\n\n\"Mr. Ortberg is a mechanical engineer,\" Larsen said. \"I hope that means he will ensure that his top message for everyone is building the best airplane means building the safest airplane in the world.\"\n\nOrtberg is set to take office on August 8, just after a two-day hearing organized by the National Transportation Safety Board in Washington on the Alaska Airlines incident.\n\nThe Alaska Airlines incident raised fresh scrutiny on Boeing and the MAX following two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019 that led to a lengthy grounding of the plane.\n\nBoeing agreed to plead guilty to a fraud charge in connection with the MAX certification as part of a plea deal with the Department of Justice, US officials announced July 24.\n\nShares of Boeing rose 1.6 percent in pre-market trading.\n\njmb/sms\n\nMore from this section\n\nInformative Research's Kelly Richards Receives MPA Elite Women Award\n\nInvestigation finds at least 973 Native American children died in US government boarding schools\n\nChurch of Scientology Forum on the Need for Sustainability", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-07-439455539", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:35:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:35:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:34:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.streetinsider.com/PRNewswire/Boeing+Board+Names+Kelly+Ortberg+President+and+CEO/23528709.html", "title": "Boeing Board Names Kelly Ortberg President and CEO", "body": "- Respected industry veteran with more than 35 years of aerospace experience\n\nARLINGTON, Va., July 31, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- Boeing [NYSE: BA] today announced that its Board of Directors has elected Robert K. \"Kelly\" Ortberg as the company's new president and chief executive officer, effective August 8, 2024. Ortberg will also serve on Boeing's Board of Directors.\n\nHe will succeed Dave Calhoun, who earlier this year announced his intention to retire from the company, having served as president and CEO since January 2020, and as a member of Boeing's Board of Directors since 2009.\n\n\"The Board conducted a thorough and extensive search process over the last several months to select the next CEO of Boeing and Kelly has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter,\" said Steven Mollenkopf, Chair of the Board. \"Kelly is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies. We look forward to working with him as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in its long history.\"\n\n\"The Board would also like to thank Dave Calhoun for his strong leadership at Boeing, first as Chair and then as CEO, when he stepped in to steer the company through the challenges of recent years,\" added Mollenkopf.\n\n\"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" said Ortberg. \"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront. There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nOrtberg, 64, brings over 35 years of aerospace leadership to this position. He began his career in 1983 as an engineer at Texas Instruments, and then joined Rockwell Collins in 1987 as a program manager and held increasingly important leadership positions at the company prior to becoming its president and CEO in 2013. After five years leading Rockwell Collins, he steered the company's integration with United Technologies and RTX until his retirement from RTX in 2021. He has held a number of important leadership posts in industry, including serving on the Board of Directors of RTX. Additionally, he serves on the Board of Directors of Aptiv PLC, a global technology company and an industry leader in vehicle systems architecture. He is the former Chair of the Aerospace Industries Association (AIA) Board of Governors.\n\nOrtberg holds a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering from the University of Iowa.\n\nAs a leading global aerospace company, Boeing develops, manufactures and services commercial airplanes, defense products and space systems for customers in more than 150 countries. As a top U.S. exporter, the company leverages the talents of a global supplier base to advance economic opportunity, sustainability and community impact. Boeing's diverse team is committed to innovating for the future, leading with sustainability, and cultivating a culture based on the company's core values of safety, quality and integrity. Join our team and find your purpose at boeing.com/careers.\n\nContact\n\nBoeing Media Relations\n\n[email protected]\n\nView original It posted a $1.4 billion loss in the second quarter as it continues to burn cash.\n\nThe accident eventually led to the resignation of CEO Dave Calhoun and departure of the company's previous board president as regulators took aim at the safety culture that was already shaken by previous crashes in 2018 and 2019.\n\nShortly after the accident, the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) barred Boeing from expanding production of its cash-cow 737 MAX family of jets without estimating how long the limitation will last.\n\nThe US aviation regulator capped production to 38 jets per month, though Reuters has reported that Boeing has been producing jets during some weeks at a much lower level.\n\nThe regulator on February 28 gave Boeing 90 days to develop a comprehensive plan to address \"systemic quality-control issues\", which the company submitted in May.\n\nHowever, the FAA's administrator has said Boeing would not be immediately allowed to increase 737 MAX production.\n\n\"During his leadership at Collins he was well liked by employees and direct reports and very personable,\" Jefferies analysts said in a note from earlier this week, after industry publication the Air Current reported Ortberg was a serious contender.\n\nJefferies said he was a \"tough negotiator\" dealing with a diverse set of customers and suppliers.\n\nA mechanical engineer, Ortberg has more than 30 years of experience in aerospace and defence, including numerous executive roles. After five years leading Rockwell Collins, he steered the company's integration with United Technologies and RTX until his retirement from RTX in 2021.\n\nHe pipped Patrick Shanahan to one of the top industrial jobs after the former Spirit Aero CEO was seen as a favourite to succeed Calhoun by some analysts and investors.\n\n\"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting {"uri": "8252397606", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:59:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:59:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:58:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.miragenews.com/boeing-board-appoints-kelly-ortberg-as-1286958/", "title": "Boeing Board Appoints Kelly Ortberg as President, CEO", "body": "Boeing [NYSE: BA] today announced that its Board of Directors has elected Robert K. \"Kelly\" Ortberg as the company's new president and chief executive officer, effective August 8, 2024. Ortberg will also serve on Boeing's Board of Directors.\n\nHe will succeed Dave Calhoun, who earlier this year announced his intention to retire from the company, having served as president and CEO since January 2020, and as a member of Boeing's Board of Directors since 2009.\n\n\"The Board conducted a thorough and extensive search process over the last several months to select the next CEO of Boeing and Kelly has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter,\" said Steven Mollenkopf, Chair of the Board. \"Kelly is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies. We look forward to working with him as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in its long history.\"\n\n\"The Board would also like to thank Dave Calhoun for his strong leadership at Boeing, first as Chair and then as CEO, when he stepped in to steer the company through the challenges of recent years,\" added Mollenkopf.\n\n\"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" said Ortberg. \"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront. There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nOrtberg, 64, brings over 35 years of aerospace leadership to this position. He began his career in 1983 as an engineer at Texas Instruments, and then joined Rockwell Collins in 1987 as a program manager and held increasingly important leadership positions at the company prior to becoming its president and CEO in 2013. After five years leading Rockwell Collins, he steered the company's integration with United Technologies and RTX until his retirement from RTX in 2021. He has held a number of important leadership posts in industry, including serving on the Board of Directors of RTX. Additionally, he serves on the Board of Directors of Aptiv PLC, a global technology company and an industry leader in vehicle systems architecture. He is the former Chair of the Aerospace Industries Association (AIA) Board of Governors.\n\nOrtberg holds a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering from the University of Iowa.\n\nAs a leading global aerospace company, Boeing develops, manufactures and services commercial airplanes, defense products and space systems for customers in more than 150 countries. As a top U.S. exporter, the company leverages the talents of a global supplier base to advance economic opportunity, sustainability and community impact. Boeing's diverse team is committed to innovating for the future, leading with sustainability, and cultivating a culture based on the company's core values of safety, quality and integrity. Join our team and find your purpose at boeing.com/careers.\n\n/Public Release.
