{"uri": "8248210748", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "04:23:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T04:23:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T04:22:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/29/one-of-these-four-people-could-be-boeings-next-ceo/", "title": "One of these four people could be Boeing's next CEO", "body": "The race for Boeing's new chief may be down to four candidates, including a new name.\n\nKelly Ortberg, the former CEO of aerospace company Rockwell Collins, is seriously being considered for the position of Boeing's chief, trade publication The Air Current reported on Sunday, citing industry officials.\n\nRockwell Collins provided aviation systems and information technology services to government agencies and aircraft manufacturers. It was acquired in 2018.\n\nOrtberg has 30 years of experience in the aerospace and space industry, according to his profile on RTX, the company which runs the former Rockwell Collins. He retired in 2021 as an advisor to the CEO of RTX.\n\nThere have been reports of three other contenders for the position following March announcement that CEO Dave Calhoun will step down by the end of the year, in the wake of the Alaska Airlines disaster in January.\n\nAnother candidate in the running is Stephanie Pope, the CEO of Boeing's commercial airplanes division. Her predecessor, Stan Deal, announced his immediate retirement at the same time as Calhoun's resignation. Pope, a third-generation employee, was formerly the plane-maker's chief operating officer and has a finance background.\n\nA third candidate is Pat Shanahan, the CEO of Spirit AeroSystems -- the supplier that built the fuselage of the Alaska 737 Max that lost its door plug midair. Earlier this month, Boeing said it would buy back Spirit, a former subsidiary, in a deal worth $4.7 billion.\n\nCurrent Boeing board chair Steve Mollenkopf is also in the running, according to Reuters. He is the former CEO of semiconductor company Qualcomm Incorporated.\n\nBoeing seems to be struggling to find a new leader. At least two people -- Larry Culp, the CEO of GE Aerospace and David Gitlin, the CEO of the home-appliances firm Carrier -- turned down Boeing's requests for the role, the Wall Street Journal reported earlier this month.\n\nThe company did not respond to Business Insider's request for comment, sent outside standard business hours.", "source": {"uri": "dnyuz.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Ortberg, who previously led Rockwell Collins, is slated to begin on August 8 and will tackle significant challenges, including reviving jet production and regaining regulator and public trust. Following the news, Boeing shares climbed by 2.9% before the market opened.\n\nBoeing has faced a turbulent period, dogged by a reputational and safety crisis following a mid-air panel incident with an Alaska Airlines-operated MAX 9 jet in January. This led to a $1.4 billion loss in the second quarter and FAA restrictions on 737 MAX jet production. The resignation of CEO Dave Calhoun and the departure of the company's board president ensued, amplifying the urgency for robust leadership.\n\nOrtberg's appointment has garnered a positive response from analysts. With over 30 years in aerospace and defense, including a successful tenure at Rockwell Collins, he is seen as a transformative figure. Boeing's Defense, Space, and Security unit has been especially hard-hit, prompting a pivot away from high-risk fixed-price contracts. The company has been facing issues in its defense and space sector, which has led to significant losses. The 737 MAX production has been capped, affecting deliveries and adding to the company's woes.Boeing on Wednesday named aerospace industry veteran Kelly Ortberg as its new President and CEO, tasking the former Rockwell Collins executive in turning around the struggling planemaker after it reported a $1.4 billion loss.\n\nOrtberg will assume his duties on August 8, Boeing said.\n\nThe company also posted a bigger quarterly loss, as its troubled defense and space business exacerbated the financial strain on the US planemaker that has already scaled back commercial aircraft production to tackle a quality crisis.\n\nBoeing's defense, space and security unit, one of its three main businesses, has lost billions of dollars in 2023 and 2022, which executives attributed to cost overruns on fixed-price contracts.\n\nSuch contracts have high margins but leave defense contractors vulnerable to inflationary pressures that have dented US corporate earnings in the last few years.\n\nThe planemaker used to bid aggressively for fixed-price contracts before the pandemic, but has now said it would pivot away from such contracts to stem losses at the business, which amounted to $1.76 billion last year.\n\nAhead of last week's Farnborough air show, the unit's head had said it was \"significantly challenged\" during the quarter.\n\nBoeing CFO Brian West said in May the planemaker will burn rather than generate cash in 2024, hamstrung by lower jet deliveries compared to last year.\n\nThe company is mired in crisis after a cabin panel on a 737 MAX 9 jets blew off midair in January, which led to a slowdown in production of its top-selling plane and a management shakeup, even as it came under intense regulatory and legal scrutiny.\n\nThe US aviation regulator has capped production of 737 MAX jets at 38 per month, though Reuters has reported that Boeing has been producing jets during some weeks at a much lower level.\n\nThat has led to lower deliveries, frustrating customers. "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://theedgemalaysia.com/node/721147", "title": "Boeing names industry veteran Kelly Ortberg as CEO, posts bigger loss", "body": "BENGALURU (July 31): Boeing on Wednesday named aerospace industry veteran Kelly Ortberg as its new president and chief executive officer, tasking the former Rockwell Collins executive in turning around the struggling plane-maker after it reported a US$1.40 billion (RM6.43 billion) loss.\n\nOrtberg will assume his duties on Aug 8, Boeing said.\n\nThe company also posted a bigger quarterly loss, as its troubled defence and space business exacerbated the financial strain on the US plane-maker that has already scaled back commercial aircraft production to tackle a quality crisis.\n\nBoeing's defence, space and security unit, one of its three main businesses, has lost billions of dollars in 2023 and 2022, which executives attributed to cost overruns on fixed-price contracts.\n\nSuch contracts have high margins but leave defence contractors vulnerable to inflationary pressures that have dented US corporate earnings in the last few years.\n\nThe plane-maker used to bid aggressively for fixed-price contracts before the pandemic, but has now said it would pivot away from such contracts to stem losses at the business, which amounted to US$1.76 billion last year.\n\nAhead of last week's Farnborough Air Show, in turning around the struggling plane maker after it reported a $1.4 billion loss.\n\nOrtberg will assume his duties on Aug. 8, Boeing said.\n\nThe company also posted a bigger quarterly loss, as its troubled defence and space business exacerbated the financial strain on the U.S. plane maker that has already scaled back commercial aircraft production to tackle a quality crisis.\n\nBoeing's Defense, Space and Security unit, one of its three main businesses, has lost billions of dollars in 2023 and 2022, which executives attributed to cost overruns on fixed-price contracts.\n\nSuch contracts have high margins but leave defence contractors vulnerable to inflationary pressures that have dented U.S. corporate earnings in the last few years.\n\nThe plane maker used to bid aggressively for fixed-price contracts before the pandemic, but has now said it would pivot away from such contracts to stem losses at the business, which amounted to $1.76 billion last year.\n\nAhead of last week's Farnborough Air Show, the unit's head had said it was \"significantly challenged\" during the quarter.\n\nBoeing CFO Brian West said in May the plane maker will burn rather than generate cash in 2024, hamstrung by lower jet deliveries compared to last year.\n\nThe company is mired in crisis after a cabin panel on a 737 MAX 9 jets blew off midair in January, which led to a slowdown in production of its top-selling plane and a management shakeup, even as it came under intense regulatory and legal scrutiny.\n\nThe U.S. aviation regulator has capped production of 737 MAX jets at 38 per month, though Reuters has reported that Boeing has been producing jets during some weeks at a much lower level.\n\nThat has led to lower deliveries, frustrating customers. Revenue fell 15% from a year earlier, and both its commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the Max, two of which crashed, killing 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration has increased its oversight of the company following mistakes including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet. It is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety.\n\nThe company is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. planemaker after it reported a $1.4 billion loss.\n\nOrtberg will assume his duties on Aug. 8, Boeing (NYSE:BA) said.\n\nThe company also posted a bigger quarterly loss, as its troubled defense and space business exacerbated the financial strain on the U.S. planemaker that has already scaled back commercial aircraft production to tackle a quality crisis.\n\nBoeing's Defense, Space and Security unit, one of its three main businesses, has lost billions of dollars in 2023 and 2022, which executives attributed to cost overruns on fixed-price contracts.\n\nSuch contracts have high margins but leave defense contractors vulnerable to inflationary pressures that have dented U.S. corporate earnings in the last few years.\n\nThe planemaker used to bid aggressively for fixed-price contracts before the pandemic, but has now said it would pivot away from such contracts to stem losses at the business, which amounted to $1.76 billion last year.\n\nAhead of last week's Farnborough Air Show, the unit's head had said it was \"significantly challenged\" during the quarter.\n\nBoeing CFO Brian West said in May the planemaker will burn rather than generate cash in 2024, hamstrung by lower jet deliveries compared to last year.\n\nThe company is mired in crisis after a cabin panel on a 737 MAX 9 jets blew off midair in January, which led to a slowdown in production of its top-selling plane and a management shakeup, even as it came under intense regulatory and legal scrutiny.\n\nThe U.S. aviation regulator has capped production of 737 MAX jets at 38 per month, though Reuters has reported that Boeing has been producing jets during some weeks at a much lower level.\n\nThat has led to lower deliveries, frustrating customers. During the second quarter, Boeing delivered a total of 92 aircraft, down 32% from last year.", "source": {"uri": "investing.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Investing.com"}, "authors": [], Revenue fell 15% from a year earlier, and both its commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the Max, two of which crashed, killing 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration has increased its oversight of the company following mistakes including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet. It is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety.\n\nWho's Donald Trump's pick for Missouri governor? He's got three. It is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nOrtberg will become CEO and president on Aug. 8, Boeing said. He emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial-airplanes division.\n\nChairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after \"a thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\"\n\nMollenkopf said Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8251159078", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:27:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:27:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:26:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://financhill.com/blog/investing/is-boeing-stock-set-to-rebound", "title": "Is Boeing Stock Set to Rebound?", "body": "Leading aerospace company The Boeing Company (NYSE:BA) has faced troubles with flight safety issues pressurizing the stock, which is down 25.7% year-to-date.\n\nThat's no surprise given the virtual laundry list of issues associated with the company right now. Boeing is facing a host of negative headlines stemming from an incident in January when a 737 Max 9 was headed to Ontario carrying 171 passengers and six crew members. After a section of the plane blew out, it returned to Portland shortly after departure.\n\nAlthough no serious injuries were reported, the event was a huge setback for the company. Alaska Airlines temporarily grounded its fleet of 65 Boeing 737 Max 9 flights. This was reflected in Boeing's first-quarter results for fiscal 2024 when quarterly revenue fell by 8% year-over-year to $16.57 billion as the company took action to slow down the production of 737 models.\n\nBut that's not the only issue Boeing has faced, and the question is whether it can earn back trust among airlines who buy its planes and customers flying them?\n\nThe troubles have mounted for Boeing in recent year. For example, Boeing agreed to plead guilty to a charge related to two crashes of 737 Max planes in 2018 and 2019, both of which were fatal.\n\nIn the Alaska Airlines case, the Department of Justice revisited the previous cases to decide whether Boeing had violated a settlement from 2021 tied to those two crashes. The plea deal allowed the company to pay an additional fine of $243.6 million with compliance monitoring.\n\nYet Boeing isn't just an airline manufacturer. There are problems in space too. After multiple delays, Boeing's Starliner spaceship finally launched in June, carrying two astronauts bound for the International Space Station (ISS). As of this writing, the spaceship's return to Earth has been delayed due to mechanical issues, leaving the astronauts stranded.\n\nIn other developments, Boeing has decided to buy back fuselage maker Spirit AeroSystems Holdings (NYSE:SPR) in an all-stock deal worth $4.7 billion. Spirit AeroSystems was spun out from Boeing in 2005. The deal is expected to close next year and offers hope that Boeing's supply chain can be improved.\n\nFollowing a host of embarrassments, Boeing's CEO David Calhoun has said he will step down from his post this year. The final straw that may have broken the camel's back so to speak was testifying to congress when he admitted to not being an engineer, and so assertions were cast that he was simply engaging in financial engineering at the cost of quality control.\n\nThe company has been looking for someone capable of filling that post, and it might have found its replacement in Spirit's CEO, Patrick Shanahan, although this is only speculation for now.\n\nBoeing's financials have been gyrating for a few years now. For example, in 2020, a year of disruptions for many companies, especially travel-related firms, Boeing suffered a sharp pullback.\n\nThe company's annual top line declined by 24% in 2020 compared to 2019. The next two years were periods of gradual revenue recovery and by 2023, Boeing finally rose above the pre-pandemic total revenue level for the first time, posting a revenue figure of $77.79 billion.\n\nThe airplane manufacturer has faced solid demand even during some tough macro conditions. For example, in 2020, the company reported a total backlog of $363 billion, including more than 4,000 commercial planes. These backlog figures have only grown over the years.\n\nIn spite of all the problems, Boeing commands a 40.6% market share in the airplane manufacturing industry, while Airbus has a 60.4% market share so it's in the interests of all stakeholders to keep Boeing alive.\n\nIn order to do so management will need to make a concerted effort to improve the bottom line. Looking back to 2019, the company had posted negative annual bottom-line figures every year. Net income over the past 3 years alone has accumulated to a loss of nearly $10 billion.\n\nWith that said, Boeing can survive a sharp drawdown in cash thanks to a rich balance sheet that has over $15 billion in liquid reserves. Nonetheless, shareholders won't take a whole lot of comfort knowing such a discussion is even being had for the former premier plane manufacturer.\n\nBoeing stock is unlikely to rebound anytime soon following 14 analysts downgrades in the most recent quarter.\n\nThe company is plagued by a host of issues at this time. The primary issue is the lack of trust both plane buyers and customers have in flying Boeing planes given the manufacturing defects that have grown in recent years.\n\nFinancially, the firm also suffers from weak gross margins that have not helped the bottom line. When you combine the lack of profitability over the past year with the expectations for losses once again this year, it's hard to be anything but pessimistic.\n\nIf there was one ray of sunshine, it would be the consensus forecast among 25 analysts at this time now is for the share price to climb back to $218 per share.\n\nThe low end of the range is $180 per share while the high-end forecast sits at $275 per share, which seems unlikely anytime soon until the anchor manufacturing defects has been fully addressed and consumers grow in confidence that the worst is of the problems are in the rearview mirror.", "source": {"uri": "financhill.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Financhill"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_737_MAX", "type": "wiki", "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/boeing-names-kelly-ortberg-ceo-113753846.html", "title": "Boeing names industry veteran Kelly Ortberg as CEO, posts bigger loss", "body": "(Reuters) -Boeing on Wednesday named aerospace industry veteran Kelly Ortberg as its new President and CEO, tasking the former Rockwell Collins executive in turning around the struggling planemaker after it reported a $1.4 billion loss.\n\nOrtberg will assume his duties on Aug. 8, Boeing said.\n\nThe company also posted a bigger quarterly loss, as its troubled defense and space business exacerbated the financial strain on the U.S. planemaker that has already scaled back commercial aircraft production to tackle a quality crisis.\n\nBoeing's Defense, Space and Security unit, one of its three main businesses, has lost billions of dollars in 2023 and 2022, which executives attributed to cost overruns on fixed-price contracts.\n\nSuch contracts have high margins but leave defense contractors vulnerable to inflationary pressures that have dented U.S. corporate earnings in the last few years.\n\nThe planemaker used to bid aggressively for fixed-price contracts before the pandemic, but has now said it would pivot away from such contracts to stem losses at the business, which amounted to $1.76 billion last year.\n\nAhead of last week's Farnborough Air Show, the unit's head had said it was \"significantly challenged\" during the quarter.\n\nBoeing CFO Brian West said in May the planemaker will burn rather than generate cash in 2024, hamstrung by lower jet deliveries compared to last year.\n\nThe company is mired in crisis after a cabin panel on a 737 MAX 9 jets blew off midair in January, which led to a slowdown in production of its top-selling plane and a management shakeup, even as it came under intense regulatory and legal scrutiny.\n\nThe U.S. aviation regulator has capped production of 737 MAX jets at 38 per month, though Reuters has reported that Boeing has been producing jets during some weeks at a much lower level.\n\nThat has led to lower deliveries, frustrating customers. During the second quarter, Boeing delivered a total of 92 aircraft, down 32% from last year.\n\n(Reporting by Abhijith Ganapavaram in Bengaluru; Editing by Arun Koyyur)", "source": {"uri": "ca.finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! {"uri": "8251106097", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:43:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:43:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:42:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/boeing-q2-earnings-preview-investors-look-for-signs-for-progress-amid-heavy-losses-174003911.html", "title": "Boeing Q2 earnings preview: Investors look for signs for progress amid heavy losses", "body": "Boeing (BA) is on deck to report second quarter results on Wednesday before the bell, another crucial moment for the plane maker to show investors that the company is slowly getting back on track -- or at least attempting to do so.\n\nFollowing a high-profile door plug blowout in January that led to the grounding of its 737-MAX 9 fleet, Boeing has been hampered by increased scrutiny of the plane maker's 737 production and safety processes, decreased overall plane production, and various whistleblower complaints documenting production issues with the MAX program and the 787 Dreamliner.\n\nLast month, Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun, who will step down at the end of the year, was pilloried in testimony in front of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, during which senators took him to task over a string of recent safety lapses and alleged wrongdoing.\n\n\"You're getting paid a heck of a lot of money. It's unbelievable; if anybody's coming out of this deal good, it's you. Why haven't you resigned?\" Senator Josh Hawley (R-Mo.) asked.\n\nCalhoun responded, \"I'm sticking this through. I am proud of having taken the job. I'm proud of our safety record, and I am proud of our Boeing people.\"\n\n\"You're proud of this safety record? Wow,\" Hawley retorted.\n\nBoeing also pleaded guilty last week to a criminal fraud conspiracy charge and agreed to pay at least $243.6 million after breaching a 2021 consent decree with the Department of Justice, with the government alleging Boeing continued risky procedures in plane construction and didn't keep accurate records following the two 737 MAX crashes in 2019 and 2020.\n\nAlong the backdrop of heavy criticism and slowdown of its business, Boeing's financial performance is expected to suffer. For Q2, Boeing is expected to report revenue of $17.46 billion per Bloomberg, a 3% drop from a year ago. Profitability will likely take a steep hit, with analysts expecting an adjusted loss per share of $1.82, resulting in an adjusted net income loss of $790.74 million, a loss over 90% greater than a year ago.\n\nBoeing pulled its full-year outlook at the start of the year given the issues it was facing, most seriously at the time the Alaska Airlines door plug blowout in January. At a Wolfe Research conference in May, Boeing CFO Brian West said Boeing would burn more cash than the nearly $4 billion it did in Q1, meaning the company could report an astounding $8 billion in negative free cash flow for the first half of the year. West will be under pressure to show Boeing's cash burn will decline as 2024 progresses.\n\nNot surprisingly, Boeing's commercial deliveries took a hit in the second quarter as well. Boeing delivered 92 commercial jets in Q2, down from the 136 planes delivered year ago, or a 32% drop. The 737 Max program had 70 deliveries in Q2, down from the 103 delivered a year ago.\n\nBefore its recent issues, Boeing had monthly delivery target of 38 737 MAX jets, with a stretch goal of 50 planes per month. Investors will be looking for progress from Boeing and Calhoun that it is indeed able to expand production and deliveries despite FAA and regulator oversight. Increased deliveries will also help Boeing's aforementioned cash burn rate.\n\nBoeing also delivered nine widebody Dreamliner jets in Q2, down from 20 a year ago. The Dreamliner jet has been the subject of a few whistleblower complaints in 2024 alone, highlighting more issues with Boeing's production and assembly processes.\n\nPras Subramanian is a reporter for Yahoo Finance covering the auto industry. {"uri": "2024-07-439474716", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:51:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:51:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:50:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/31/business/boeing-kelly-ortberg-ceo.html", "title": "Boeing Names Robert Ortberg as Its Chief Executive", "body": "The company has been under pressure to improve quality and safety after a panel blew away from a 737 Max plane during an Alaska Airlines flight in January.\n\nBoeing's board named the plane maker's next chief executive on Wednesday, putting Robert K. Ortberg, a longtime aerospace executive, in charge of the effort to turn the page on a crisis prompted by a panel blowing off one of the company's planes earlier this year.\n\nMr. Ortberg, known as Kelly, will inherit a long list of difficult tasks, including overseeing sweeping cultural changes at Boeing, carrying out the acquisition of one of the company's most important suppliers, shoring up its supply chain as it seeks to increase production, and preparing for development of its next generation of planes. His appointment takes effect on Aug. 8.\n\n\"Kelly is an experienced leader who is deeply respected in the aerospace industry, with a well-earned reputation for building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies,\" Steven Mollenkopf, the board chairman, said in a statement. \"We look forward to working with him as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in its long history.\"\n\nMr. Ortberg, 64, brings decades of industry experience and an outsider's perspective to the role. He is a former chief executive of Rockwell Collins, which made electronic systems and other technology for aircraft.\n\nBoeing's board had been searching for a new chief executive since March, when Dave Calhoun announced plans to step down. Mr. Calhoun, a member of Boeing's board since 2009, was appointed chief executive in 2019 to steer the company through crisis after two fatal crashes in which 346 people died.\n\nThough unrelated to the earlier crashes, the panel incident earlier this year reignited questions about the quality of Boeing's planes. The company has since made a raft of changes, including adding more internal inspections, increasing scrutiny of suppliers, expanding training for new hires and simplifying processes and procedures.", June, compared with a roughly $150m loss last year.\n\nAs well as the troubles in its commercial unit, the hole reflected increased costs in the company's defence business, which often involves fixed {"uri": "8252438453", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:23:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:23:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:22:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-a-loss-of-more-than-1-4-billion/article_79de4083-65e2-5577-86aa-565c03ce9ec0.html", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts a loss of more than $1.4 billion in second quarter", "body": "Associated Press\n\nBoeing lost more than $1.4 billion in the second quarter and said a longtime industry executive will take over as chief executive of the troubled aircraft manufacturer next week.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, 64, a former CEO at aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun as CEO, the company said.\n\nShares rose more than 2% before the opening bell Wednesday.\n\nBoeing's loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected. Revenue fell 15% from a year earlier, and both its commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the Max, two of which crashed, killing 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration has increased its oversight of the company following mistakes including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet. It is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety.\n\nPeople are also reading... Rosie's Pub owner leaves beloved downtown business after 21 years Bloomington approves $6.8M contract for roadwork REO Speedwagon, Loverboy to perform in Bloomington this fall 17-year-old McLean County teen charged as an adult for attempted murder Bear seen in Illinois likely swam across Ohio River from Kentucky, wildlife official says Bloomington man denied release from treatment center 15 years after infant daughter's death 2 suspects arrested after shots fired on Morris Avenue in Bloomington Bloomington woman pleads guilty to burglary charge in McLean County Bloomington businessman giving backpacks to families in need Records show deputy's behavior, integrity questioned years before shooting of Sonya Massey UPDATE: Missing teen from Normal found safe Funerals pending for July 27 2 men detained in McLean County after highway shooting in Bloomington Bloomington native, trick rider Lindy Lica performs hometown show at McLean County Fair Record of deputy who killed Sonya Massey should have raised flags, experts say\n\nThe company is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nOrtberg will become CEO and president on Aug. 8, Boeing said. He emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial-airplanes division.\n\nChairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after \"a thorough and extensive search process\" and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\"\n\nMollenkopf said Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. We look forward to working with him as he leads Boeing through this consequential period in its long history,\" board chair Steven Mollenkopf said in a statement.\n\nThe board's emphasis on \"building strong teams and running complex engineering and manufacturing companies\" is likely no coincidence.\n\nBoeing has been under intense scrutiny and suffering low employee morale for years following a series of serious safety incidents that left the quality of its planes in doubt. Starting with two 737 Max crashes in 2018 and 2019, and highlighted most recently by an Alaska Airlines jet that lost a piece of its fuselage in an explosive decompression mid-flight earlier this year, the company is struggling to regain its image as the premier American aerospace manufacturer.\n\nCruising Altitude: Another Boeing plane issue? Don't fall for the headlines.\n\nRegulators capped the production rate of the 737 Max as part of their response to quality issues on the line, and the company announced a quality control and improvement plan in May that it's working to enact.\n\nThe planemaker insists that it's on the path to a turnaround. In a media open house earlier this summer, executives told journalists that the safety culture at the company is changing for the better. But Boeing was quickly sanctioned by the National Transportation Safety Board after the presentation for revealing non-public details about the investigation into the Alaska Airlines incident.\n\nOrtberg has a big job ahead of him continuing that turnaround when he steps into Boeing's C-suite next week.\n\n\"I'm extremely honored and humbled to join this iconic company,\" Ortberg said in a statement. \"Boeing has a tremendous and rich history as a leader and pioneer in our industry, and I'm committed to working together with the more than 170,000 dedicated employees of the company to continue that tradition, with safety and quality at the forefront. There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nZach Wichter is a travel reporter for USA TODAY based in New York. {"uri": "2024-07-439515770", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:26:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:26:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:54:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/illinois/articles/2024-07-31/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-a-loss-of-more-than-1-4-billion-in-second-quarter", "title": "Boeing Names New CEO as It Posts a Loss of More Than $1.4 Billion in Second Quarter", "body": "Boeing lost more than $1.4 billion in the second quarter and said a longtime industry executive will take over as chief executive of the troubled aircraft manufacturer next week.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\" Ortberg, 64, a former CEO at Rockwell Collins, will succeed c as CEO, the company said.\n\nBoeing's loss was wider and revenue lower than Wall Street expected. Revenue fell 15% from a year earlier, and both its commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the Max, two of which crashed, killing 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration has increased its oversight of the company following mistakes including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet. It is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety.\n\nThe company is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nShares rose more than 3% before the opening bell Wednesday.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8252600223", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:09:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:09:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:04:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13693623/TIMELINE-Boeing-names-Ortberg-boss-amid-ongoing-crisis.html", "title": "TIMELINE-Boeing names Ortberg top boss amid ongoing crisis", "body": "July 31 (Reuters) -\n\nAfter a months-long search, Boeing has appointed aerospace industry veteran Kelly Ortberg as its new CEO, entrusting the former Rockwell Collins executive with the monumental job of turning around the struggling planemaker.\n\nOrtberg will navigate Boeing through several key challenges including slow jet production rate, quality issues at the planemaker and restoring confidence with regulators, the industry and the public.\n\nBoeing, one of two global planemaking giants, has faced a reputational and safety crisis after a Jan. 5 mid-air panel blowout on a 737 MAX 9 jet, that led to the eventual resignation of CEO Dave Calhoun.\n\nHere is a timeline of recent issues surrounding Boeing:\n\nOCTOBER 2018: A Lion Air MAX plane crashes in Indonesia, killing all 189 people on board.\n\nNOVEMBER 2018: The FAA and Boeing say they are evaluating the need for software or design changes to 737 MAX jets following the Lion Air crash. MARCH 2019: An Ethiopian Airlines MAX crashes, killing all 157 people on board. China's aviation regulator becomes the first in the world to ground the MAX, followed by others including the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration. APRIL 2019: The FAA forms an international team to review the safety of the 737 MAX. Boeing cuts monthly production by nearly 20%. JULY 2019: Boeing posts its largest ever quarterly loss.\n\nSEPTEMBER 2019: Boeing's board of directors creates a permanent safety committee to oversee development, manufacturing and operation of its aircraft.\n\nOCTOBER 2019: Boeing fires Kevin McAllister, the top executive of its commercial airplanes division. DECEMBER 2020: The company fires CEO Dennis Muilenburg in the wake of the twin crashes.\n\nJANUARY 2020: Boeing suspends 737 production, its biggest assembly-line halt in more than 20 years.\n\nMAY 2020: Boeing resumes 737 MAX production at a \"low rate.\" JUNE 2020: Boeing begins a series of long-delayed flight tests of its redesigned 737 MAX with regulators at the controls. SEPTEMBER 2020: An 18-month investigation by a U.S. House of Representatives panel finds Boeing failed in its design and development of the MAX as well as its transparency with the FAA, and that the FAA failed in oversight and certification.\n\nNOVEMBER 2020: The U.S. FAA lifts the grounding order, allowing the 737 MAX to fly again. DECEMBER 2020: Congress passes legislation to reform how the FAA certifies new airplanes, including requiring manufacturers to disclose certain safety-critical information to the FAA.\n\nJANUARY 2021: The European Union Aviation Safety Agency approves the MAX's return to service in Europe. MARCH 2021: China's aviation regulator says major safety concerns with the MAX needed to be \"properly addressed\" before conducting flight tests.\n\nAPRIL 2021: Boeing halts 737 MAX deliveries after electrical problems re-ground part of the fleet.\n\nNOVEMBER 2021: Current and former Boeing company directors reach a $237.5 million settlement with shareholders to settle lawsuits over safety oversight of the 737 MAX.\n\nOCTOBER 2022: The FAA tells Boeing that some key documents submitted as part of the certification review of the 737 MAX 7 are incomplete and others need a reassessment. DECEMBER 2022: Congress agrees to extend a deadline for new standards for modern cockpit alerts stemming from the 2020 legislation after intense lobbying from Boeing.\n\nAPRIL 2023: Boeing pauses deliveries of some 737 MAXs to deal with a new supplier quality problem involving non-compliant fittings. JULY 2023: Boeing's first delivery of the 737 MAX 7 is delayed to 2024.\n\nAUGUST 2023: Boeing identifies a new 737 MAX supplier quality problem involving improperly drilled holes on the aft pressure bulkhead.\n\nSEPTEMBER 2023: Boeing 737 MAX deliveries fall to their lowest levels since August 2021.\n\nDECEMBER 2023: Boeing makes its first direct delivery of a 787 Dreamliner to China since 2019, seen as a precursor to China potentially unfreezing deliveries of the 737 MAX. JANUARY 2024: A mid-air cabin blowout compels Alaska Air to perform an emergency landing of its recently acquired 737 MAX 9 aircraft, prompting the FAA to ground 171 of these jets and initiate an investigation. The FAA also bars Boeing from increasing MAX output, but lifts the grounding of MAX-9s once inspections were completed. FEBRUARY 2024: The U.S. National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) published its preliminary report on the Alaska Air incident involving a Boeing 737 MAX jet. According to the investigation, the door panel that flew off the jet mid-flight appeared to be missing four key bolts.\n\nMARCH 2024:\n\n** The FAA's 737 MAX production audit finds multiple instances where Boeing and Spirit AeroSystems allegedly failed to comply with manufacturing quality control requirements. This comes days after Boeing said it was in preliminary talks to buy Spirit.\n\n** The ongoing crisis may mean Boeing will need more time to hit key financial targets for coming years, its CFO warns.\n\n** Airbus clinches orders for 65 jets from two of Boeing's key Asian customers, Japan Airlines and Korean Air.\n\n** The U.S. planemaker says CEO Dave Calhoun will step down and announces that Stan Deal, Boeing Commercial Airplanes President and CEO, will be succeeded by Stephanie Pope.\n\nMAY 2024\n\n** The U.S. Department of Justice says Boeing\n\nbreached\n\nits obligations in a 2021 agreement that shielded it from criminal prosecution over 737 MAX crashes in 2018 and 2019.\n\nJULY 2024:\n\n** Boeing acquires Spirit AeroSystems back in an all-stock deal for $4.7 billion in equity value. The deal comes as Boeing, which had sold Spirit in 2005 to cut costs, attempts to solve its quality hurdles and accelerate jet deliveries.\n\n** Boeing agrees to\n\nplead guilty\n\nto a criminal fraud conspiracy charge and pay a fine of $243.6 million to resolve the U.S. Justice Department investigation into the two 737 MAX fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019.\n\n** Boeing names former Rockwell Collins executive\n\nKelly Ortberg\n\nas its new president and CEO after a months-long search.\n\n(Reporting by David Gaffen, Nathan Gomes and Pratyush Thakur; Editing by Leslie Adler, Devika Syamnath, {"uri": "8252440820", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:27:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:27:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:24:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/boeings-q2-earnings-huge-revenue-121850103.html", "title": "Boeing's Q2 Earnings: Huge Revenue Decline, Lower Deliveries, Names Former Aerospace Industries Association Chair Kelly Ortberg As New CEO", "body": "Boeing Co (NYSE:BA) reported second-quarter 2024 results and named Kelly Ortberg its new President and CEO, effective August 8, 2024.\n\nBoeing reported a second-quarter revenue decline of 15% year-over-year to $16.866 billion, missing the consensus of $17.23 billion.\n\nAdjusted loss per share expanded to $(2.90) from $(0.93) in the same quarter of 2024, missing the consensus of $(1.91).\n\nThe company stated that the results primarily reflect lower commercial delivery volume and losses on fixed-price defense development programs.\n\nBoeing recorded an adjusted operating loss of $(1.392) billion for the quarter, compared to $(390) million a year ago. The core operating loss margin was (8.3)%.\n\nCommercial Airplanes revenue fell 32% YoY to $6.003 billion, reflecting lower deliveries and planned higher period costs, including research and development.\n\nDeliveries declined by 32%, and 92 airplanes were delivered, and the backlog included over 5,400 airplanes valued at $437 billion.\n\nThe 737 program gradually increased production during the quarter and still plans to increase production to 38 per month by year end.\n\nDefense, Space & Security revenue fell 3% year over year to $6.021 billion. The backlog was $59 billion, of which 31% represents orders from customers outside the U.S.\n\nGlobal Services revenue grew by 3% YoY to $4.889 billion. The operating margin contracted 20 bps to 17.8%, reflecting higher commercial volume and mix.\n\nOperating cash outflow for the six months ended June 30 totaled $(7.285) billion, compared to cash provided of $2.557 billion YoY; free cash outflow was $(4.3) billion.\n\nDebt was $57.9 billion, up from $47.9 billion at the beginning of the quarter due to the issuance of new debt.\n\nAt the end of the quarter, cash and investments in marketable securities totaled $12.6 billion, and the total company backlog was $515.874 billion.\n\nAlso Read: Boeing Resumes 737 MAX Deliveries To China After Regulatory Delay: Report\n\nAdditionally, Boeing announced Robert K. \"Kelly\" Ortberg as the company's new president and chief executive officer, effective August 8, 2024. Ortberg will also serve on Boeing's Board of Directors.\n\nOrtberg, 64, has over 35 years of aerospace experience. He began at Texas Instruments in 1983, joined Rockwell Collins in 1987, and became CEO in 2013.\n\nHe led its integration with United Technologies and RTX until 2021. He serves on the boards of RTX and Aptiv PLC and is a former Chair of the Aerospace Industries Association.\n\nPrice Action: BA shares are trading higher by 2.06% at $190.70 premarket at the last check on Wednesday.\n\nPhoto via Shutterstock\n\n\"ACTIVE INVESTORS' SECRET WEAPON\" Supercharge Your Stock Market Game with the #1 \"news & everything else\" trading tool: Benzinga Pro - Click here to start Your 14-Day Trial Now!\n\nGet the latest stock analysis from Benzinga?\n\nThis article Boeing's Q2 Earnings: Huge Revenue Decline, Lower Deliveries, Names Former Aerospace Industries Association Chair Kelly Ortberg As New CEO originally appeared on Benzinga.com", "source": {"uri": "finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! He retired in 2021 as an advisor to the CEO of RTX.\n\nThere have been reports of three other contenders for the position following March announcement that CEO Dave Calhoun will step down by the end of the year, in the wake of the Alaska Airlines disaster in January.\n\nAnother candidate in the running is Stephanie Pope, the CEO of Boeing's commercial airplanes division. Her predecessor, Stan Deal, announced his immediate retirement at the same time as Calhoun's resignation. Pope, a third-generation employee, was formerly the plane-maker's chief operating officer and has a finance background.\n\nA third candidate is Pat Shanahan, the CEO of Spirit AeroSystems -- the supplier that built the fuselage of the Alaska 737 Max that lost its door plug midair. Earlier this month, Boeing said it would buy back Spirit, a former subsidiary, in a deal worth $4.7 billion.\n\nCurrent Boeing board chair Steve Mollenkopf is also in the running, according to Reuters. He is the former CEO of semiconductor company Qualcomm Incorporated.\n\nBoeing seems to be struggling to find a new leader. Revenue fell 15% from a year earlier, and both its commercial planes business and defence unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing. The company agreed to plead guilty to fraud in connection with the Max jetliner, two of which crashed, killing 346 people.\n\nThe US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has increased its oversight of the company following mistakes including the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet.\n\nIt is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that affect safety.\n\nThe company is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor.\n\nIt is still trying to {"uri": "8252391764", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:55:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:55:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:54:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/business/money-report/boeing-is-set-to-report-results-before-the-market-opens-heres-what-wall-street-expects/3474013/", "title": "Boeing reports wider-than-expected loss, weaker revenue", "body": "The company is under increased federal scrutiny after a door plug blew out from a nearly new 737 Max 9 in January.\n\nBoeing reported a bigger loss and weaker revenue than analysts expected for the second quarter as both its commercial airplane and defense programs continued to struggle.\n\nHere's how Boeing performed in the second quarter compared with estimates compiled by LSEG:\n\n\"Despite a challenging quarter, we are making substantial progress strengthening our quality management system and positioning our company for the future,\" CEO Dave Calhoun said in an earnings release on Wednesday.\n\nBoeing reported a net loss for the period of $1.44 billion, or $2.33 per share, compared with a loss of $149 million, or 25 cents per share, during the year-earlier period. On an adjusted basis, the company reported a loss of $2.90 per share, coming in nearly $1 per share under analyst expectations, according to LSEG.\n\nRevenue for the quarter was down 15% to $16.87.\n\nBoeing is trying to regain its footing after a door plug blowout from a nearly-new 737 Max at the start of the year reignited additional scrutiny from regulators and further slowed deliveries of new, more fuel-efficient jets to airlines.\n\nLower deliveries and production have pushed back some of Boeing's financial targets.\n\nCFO Brian West warned in May that the company would continue to burn cash in the second quarter, similar to the first, largely due to lower production and delivery rates than expected.\n\nOn Wednesday, the manufacturer reported negative free cash flow of $4.3 billion for the second quarter.\n\nBoeing was producing its best-selling Max planes a pace in the mid-20s per month in the last few months, far from its target of 38 a month.\n\nStephanie Pope, CEO of Boeing's commercial airplane unit, told reporters ahead of the Farnborough Airshow outside London earlier this month that the company is trying to make lasting changes to training and quality control, admitting that the company has disappointed customers.\n\n\"We've impacted their business and we haven't met the commitments and lived up to being the partner that they expect and they need us to be,\" she said. \"This plan is not a three-month plan,\" said Pope. \"I call it transformational because some of these actions will take years.\"\n\nBoeing's other business units have also faced cost overruns and delays, like its defense unit which is building the two Boeing 747 aircraft that will serve as Air Force One, which are behind schedule.", "source": {"uri": Here's what Wall Street expects", "body": "The company is under increased federal scrutiny after a door plug blew out from a nearly new 737 Max 9 in January.\n\nBoeing is set to report results before the market opens on Wednesday. Analysts are expecting another loss and lower revenue for the aircraft manufacturer that continues to struggle with the fallout from its safety and manufacturing crises.\n\nHere's how analysts expect Boeing performed in the second quarter, according to estimates compiled by LSEG:\n\nBoeing is trying to regain its footing after a door plug blowout from a nearly-new 737 Max at the start of the year reignited additional scrutiny from regulators and further slowed deliveries of new, more fuel-efficient jets to airlines.\n\nIn addition to the impact from the door plug accident in January, Boeing, as well as rival Airbus, are dealing with thousands of new workers and a supply chain that can't keep up with production demands after a demand plunge during the pandemic roiled their businesses.\n\nLower deliveries and production have pushed back some of Boeing's financial targets. CFO Brian West warned in May that the company would likely burn another roughly $4 billion in the second quarter, similar to the first, largely due to lower production and delivery rates than expected. disappointed customers.\n\n\"We've impacted their business and we haven't met the commitments and lived up to being the partner that they expect and they need us to be,\" she said. \"This plan is not {"uri": "8252306034", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:03:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:03:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:02:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://www.cnbc.com/2024/07/31/boeing-ba-earnings-q2-2024.html", "title": "Boeing is set to report results before the market opens. Analysts are expecting another loss and lower revenue for the aircraft manufacturer that continues to struggle with the fallout from its safety and manufacturing crises.\n\nHere's how analysts expect Boeing performed in the second quarter, according to estimates compiled by LSEG:\n\nBoeing is trying to regain its footing after a door plug blowout from a nearly-new 737 Max at the start of the year reignited additional scrutiny from regulators and further slowed deliveries of new, more fuel-efficient jets to airlines.\n\nIn addition to the impact from the door plug accident in January, Boeing, as well as rival Airbus, are dealing with thousands of new workers and a supply chain that can't keep up with production demands after a demand plunge during the pandemic roiled their businesses.\n\nLower deliveries and production have pushed back some of Boeing's financial targets. Boeing posted a bigger quarterly loss, as its troubled defense and space business exacerbated the financial strain on the U.S. planemaker that has already scaled back commercial aircraft production to tackle a quality crisis.\n\nIts second-quarter net loss stood at $1.44 billion, the company said on Wednesday, compared with $149 million a year ago.\n\nBoeing's Defense, Space and Security unit, one of its three main businesses, has lost billions of dollars in 2023 and 2022, which executives attributed to cost overruns on fixed-price contracts.\n\nSuch contracts have high margins but leave defense contractors vulnerable to inflationary pressures that have dented U.S. corporate earnings in the last few years.\n\nThe planemaker used to bid aggressively for fixed-price contracts before the pandemic, but has now said it would pivot away from such contracts to stem losses at the business, which amounted to $1.76 billion last year.\n\nAhead of last week's Farnborough Air Show, the unit's head had said it was \"significantly challenged\" during the quarter.\n\nBoeing CFO Brian West said in May the planemaker will burn rather than generate cash in 2024, hamstrung by lower jet deliveries compared to last year.\n\nThe company is mired in crisis after a cabin panel on a 737 MAX 9 jets blew off midair in January, which led to a slowdown in production of its top-selling plane and a management shakeup, even as it came under intense regulatory and legal scrutiny.\n\nThe U.S. aviation regulator has capped production of 737 MAX jets at 38 per month, though Reuters has reported that Boeing has been producing jets during some weeks at a much lower level.\n\nThat has led to lower deliveries, frustrating customers. During the second quarter, Boeing delivered a total of 92 aircraft, down 32% from last year.\n\nThe company is searching for a new CEO to replace Dave Calhoun, who has decided to step down by year's end.\n\n(Reporting by Abhijith Ganapavaram in Bengaluru; Editing by Arun Koyyur)", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reuters@aol.com", "name": {"uri": "8252252553", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:35:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:35:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:34:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/boeing-doj-plea-deal-pilot-objection-1932096", "title": "'Travesty of Justice': Former Pilot Urges Court to Reject Boeing Plea Deal", "body": "A former Boeing pilot has recommended that the court dismiss the aerospace giant's plea deal with the Department of Justice, in a letter containing wide-ranging allegations against the company's \"criminal corporate culture.\"\n\nIn a motion filed with a U.S. District Court in Texas, Anthony Keyter urged Judge Reed O'Connor \"not to accept the Boeing plea agreement in its present form,\" arguing that it would be \"a gross travesty of justice to single out and settle one count of fraud by Boeing - while ignoring numerous other serious felonies.\"\n\nKeyter is a Federal Aviation Administration-certified pilot who claims to have worked as a Boeing senior instructor pilot for 17 years. He is also a long-time litigious opponent of Boeing, and has previously filed murder charges against the company, as well as Air India and former President George W. Bush, according to court records in Maine and Washington.\n\nIn the case of the latter, Maine Magistrate Judge Margaret Kravchuk warned Keyter that \"repeated filing of frivolous pleadings\" would result in him being prohibited from further filings with the court.\n\nNewsweek has contacted Boeing to comment on the allegations and their past dealings with Keyter.\n\nOn Wednesday evening, Boeing and the Department of Justice submitted their finalized plea agreement with a Texas district court.\n\nIf approved by O'Connor, the deal will see Boeing plead guilty to one count of \"conspiracy to defraud the United States\" for misleading regulators into approving the 737 MAX jetliner involved in the fatal 2018 and 2019 crashes.\n\nBoeing will also be forced to pay a $243.6 million fine, invest at least $455 million in its safety and compliance programs, and undergo three years of probation.\n\nIn his amicus curiae brief - an offer of relevant information or insight from an individual not party to a legal case - Keyter argued that Boeing's plea deal with the Department of Justice should be thrown out or replaced.\n\n\"The plea agreement reached between the government and the Boeing Company brings some restitution by way of a fine to the government, but to the government alone,\" the brief read.\n\nHe goes on to argue that a separate plea agreement should be made with the families of those who died onboard the 737 MAX \"for the crime of mass murder committed by Boeing against their loved ones.\"\n\n\"Flight safety warnings issued by Anthony Keyter as Senior Boeing Instructor, which were simply ignored, led directly to further crimes of mass murder in four completely avoidable air accidents,\" he added.\n\nKeyter was referring to the 2018 and 2019 737 MAX crashes, as well as Asiana Flight 214 (2013) and Air India Flight IX-812 (2010), which together resulted in the deaths of over 500 passengers and crew.\n\nKeyter, acting as his own attorney, also accused Boeing of several other crimes - including \"massive and ongoing stock exchange fraud,\" witness tampering and retaliation, and conspiracy to murder - which he said collectively attest \"to a criminal corporate culture\" at Boeing.", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newsweek"}, "authors": [{"uri": "hugh_cameron@newsweek.com", "name": "Hugh Cameron", "type": {"uri": "2024-07-439481170", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:57:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:57:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:34:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/top-news/articles/2024-07-31/boeing-posts-bigger-loss-as-defense-business-struggles-to-turn-around", "title": "Boeing Posts Bigger Loss as Defense Business Struggles to Turn Around", "body": "(Reuters) - Boeing posted a bigger quarterly loss, as its troubled defense and space business exacerbated the financial strain on the U.S. planemaker that has already scaled back commercial aircraft production to tackle a quality crisis.\n\nIts second-quarter net loss stood at $1.44 billion, the company said on Wednesday, compared with $149 million a year ago.\n\nBoeing's Defense, Space and Security unit, one of its three main businesses, has lost billions of dollars in 2023 and 2022, which executives attributed to cost overruns on fixed-price contracts.\n\nSuch contracts have high margins but leave defense contractors vulnerable to inflationary pressures that have dented U.S. corporate earnings in the last few years.\n\nThe planemaker used to bid aggressively for fixed-price contracts before the pandemic, but has now said it would pivot away from such contracts to stem losses at the business, which amounted to $1.76 billion last year.\n\nAhead of last week's Farnborough Air Show, the unit's head had said it was \"significantly challenged\" during the quarter.\n\nBoeing CFO Brian West said in May the planemaker will burn rather than generate cash in 2024, hamstrung by lower jet deliveries compared to last year.\n\nThe company is mired in crisis after a cabin panel on a 737 MAX 9 jets blew off midair in January, which led to a slowdown in production of its top-selling plane and a management shakeup, even as it came under intense regulatory and legal scrutiny.\n\nThe U.S. aviation regulator has capped production of 737 MAX jets at 38 per month, though Reuters has reported that Boeing has been producing jets during some weeks at a much lower level.\n\nThat has led to lower deliveries, frustrating customers. During the second quarter, Boeing delivered a total of 92 aircraft, down 32% from last year.\n\nThe company is searching for a new CEO to replace Dave Calhoun, who has decided to step down by year's {"uri": "8252622701", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:21:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:21:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:18:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "url": "https://finimize.com/content/boeing-faces-huge-losses-as-defense-business-struggles", "title": "Boeing Faces Huge Losses As Defense Business Struggles", "body": "Boeing is reeling from a $1.44 billion quarterly loss, driven by persistent woes in its defense and space division.\n\nWhat does this mean?\n\nThe aerospace giant's financial troubles aren't new. Boeing's Defense, Space, and Security (DSS) unit has been a significant drag, posting billions in losses in 2023 and 2022. These struggles stem largely from cost overruns on fixed-price contracts, which, while potentially lucrative, have left Boeing vulnerable to inflationary pressures. In efforts to curb these losses, Boeing is now easing off on aggressive bidding for such contracts. The headwinds were acknowledged just before the Farnborough Air Show, and Boeing's Chief Financial Officer has already warned of cash burn throughout 2024 due to lower jet deliveries compared to last year.\n\nBoeing's defense business woes are part of a broader struggle affecting the company. The US aviation regulator currently limits Boeing's production of 737 MAX jets to 38 per month, but production has fallen short at times, causing customer discontent. Boeing's deliveries in the second quarter amounted to 92 aircraft, marking a 32% decline from the same period last year. These operational setbacks, coupled with financial strain, are contributing to investor unease about Boeing's capacity to recover swiftly.\n\nThe bigger picture: Navigating a challenging flight path.\n\nBoeing's issues highlight broader challenges in the aerospace sector, including the impacts of inflation and production hiccups. The exploding cabin panel incident in January has compounded these troubles, inviting regulatory and legal scrutiny. The search for a new CEO to replace Dave Calhoun, who will step down by year-end, adds another layer of uncertainty. As Boeing navigates these turbulent times, its strategic choices will be crucial not just for its recovery but for setting precedents in the aerospace industry at large.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8252750086", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:42:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:42:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:42:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://lethbridgeherald.com/business/2024/07/31/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-loss-of-more-than-14-billion-in-second-quarter/", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts loss of more than $1.4 billion in second quarter", "body": "Boeing named a longtime aerospace industry veteran Wednesday as its next chief executive, who will take over a company rocked by legal, regulatory and production problems and mounting financial repercussions.\n\nRobert \"Kelly\"\u009d Ortberg, a former CEO at Boeing supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun as CEO and president effective Aug. 8, the company said. Calhoun said in March that he would retire at the end of the year, and analysts generally praised the quicker transition.\n\nBoeing announced its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and the company's revenue lower than Wall Street's dismal expectations, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money.\n\nThe disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing, which is the subject of multiple investigations into its safety culture and manufacturing quality.\n\nThe American aerospace giant agreed to plead guilty this month to a federal fraud charge in connection with its 737 Max jetliner and two crashes that killed 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration increased its oversight of the company and limited the number of planes it could produce after a panel blew off an Alaska Airlines Max flying at an altitude of 16,000 feet. No one was seriously hurt, but the frightening incident and subsequent scrutiny have damaged Boeing's reputation.\n\nBoeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\"\u009d and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\"\u009d Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies, Mollenkopf said.\n\nThe company waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg, a spokesperson said. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021.\n\nOrtberg emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial airplanes division.\n\nOrtberg led Rockwell Collins from 2013 to 2018, when it merged with United Technologies and wound up as part of RTX, the company formerly known as Raytheon. He retired from RTX in 2021.\n\nRichard Aboulafia, a longtime aerospace analyst and consultant and recently a harsh critic of the company, said the hire is great news for Boeing.\n\n\"He is a deeply respected leader in the aerospace industry, and brings more hope for a better future than the company has enjoyed in decades,\"\u009d Aboulafia said.\n\nDeutsche Bank analyst Scott Deuschle said Ortberg \"has an engineering background, experience in the aviation industry, and experience as a public company CEO.\"\u009d\n\nIn a statement issued by Boeing, Ortberg said, \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\"\n\nCalhoun will serve as a special adviser to the Boeing board until next March.\n\nLike Calhoun, who took over as CEO in the wake of the two Max crashes, Ortberg inherits the leadership of a company facing ongoing crises and criticism from inside and outside the company.\n\nBoeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety. It is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It faces a threatened strike this fall by its largest union, the International Association of Machinists.\n\nThe company is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max.\n\nThe quarterly earnings reported Wednesday reflected the continuing challenges at Boeing. The reported loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier. Since the start of 2019, Boeing has lost more than $25 billion.\n\nExcluding special items, the second-quarter loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey.\n\nRevenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion. The commercial airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million, and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines - 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier.\n\nThe FAA limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end.\n\nBoeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine it agreed to pay as part of its plea deal with the Justice Department in connection with development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the agreement, which also calls for the appointment of an independent compliance monitor and for Boeing to invest at least $455 million \"in its compliance, quality, and safety programs.\"\u009d\n\nMany families of the people who died in the two Max crashes, which took place off the coast of Indonesia in 2018 and in Ethiopia less than five months later, oppose the deal and plan to ask the judge to reject it.\n\nBoeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets.
