{"uri": "8252753637", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:46:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:46:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:44:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/3037358-kelly-ortberg-returns-to-lead-boeing-amid-safety-crisis", "title": "Kelly Ortberg Returns to Lead Boeing Amid Safety Crisis | Law-Order", "body": "Kelly Ortberg, former head of Rockwell Collins, is set to take the reins at Boeing on August 8. With a strong engineering background and industry experience, Ortberg faces the task of rebuilding relationships with customers, regulators, and lawmakers following a recent safety crisis. Analysts are optimistic about his appointment.\n\nKelly Ortberg, the former Rockwell Collins boss tapped to lead Boeing, brings a balance of industry know-how and fresh perspective to the troubled airline manufacturer. Ortberg is set to start on August 8.\n\nHe will need to rebuild trust with Boeing's major customers, regulators, and lawmakers after a safety crisis earlier this year. Ortberg, a mechanical engineer with extensive experience, previously led key aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins and guided its integration with United Technologies until his 2021 retirement.\n\nIndustry analysts and executives are optimistic about Ortberg's appointment. Rep Rick Larsen emphasized the need for Boeing's new leadership to focus on building the safest airplanes, and others noted his reputation as a good listener and tough negotiator. Boeing's decision to waive the mandatory retirement age suggests strong confidence in Ortberg's leadership.", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Devdiscourse"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rockwell_Collins", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Rockwell Collins"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Engineering", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Engineering"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Technologies", "type": "org", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "United Technologies"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerospace", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Aerospace"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanical_engineering", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Mechanical engineering"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airplane", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Airplane"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Fleet_Maintenance", "label": "dmoz/Business/Transportation and Logistics/Fleet Maintenance", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 78}], "image": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/remote.axd?https://devdiscourse.blob.core.windows.net/imagegallery/27_05_2019_11_49_14_1279651.jpg?width=920&format=jpeg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9771357", "eventUri": "eng-9771357", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-08", "textStart": 86, "textEnd": 94, "freq": 2}], "sentiment": 0.2784313725490195, "wgt": 460136771, "relevance": 2}
{"uri": "8252755282", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:47:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:47:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:45:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/business/2024/07/31/boeing-names-new-ceo-as-it-posts-loss-of-more-than-14-billion-in-second-quarter/", "title": "Boeing names new CEO as it posts loss of more than $1.4 billion in second quarter - Medicine Hat News", "body": "FILE - A Boeing 737 MAX aircraft is shown on the assembly line at the Boeing facility in Renton, Wash., June 25, 2024. Boeing reports earnings on Wednesday, July 31, 2024. (Jennifer Buchanan/The Seattle Times via AP, Pool, File)Boeing named a longtime aerospace industry veteran Wednesday as its next chief executive, who will take over a company rocked by legal, regulatory and production problems and mounting financial repercussions. Robert \"Kelly\"\u009d Ortberg, a former CEO at Boeing supplier Rockwell Collins, will succeed David Calhoun as CEO and president effective Aug. 8, the company said. Calhoun said in March that he would retire at the end of the year, and analysts generally praised the quicker transition. Boeing announced its new CEO as it reported a loss of more than $1.4 billion on falling revenue during the second quarter. The loss was wider and the company's revenue lower than Wall Street's dismal expectations, as both Boeing's commercial-airplanes business and defense unit lost money. The disappointing results come at a tumultuous time for Boeing, which is the subject of multiple investigations into its safety culture and manufacturing quality. The American aerospace giant agreed to plead guilty this month to a federal fraud charge in connection with its 737 Max jetliner and two crashes that killed 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration increased its oversight of the company and limited the number of planes it could produce after a panel blew off an Alaska Airlines Max flying at an altitude of 16,000 feet. No one was seriously hurt, but the frightening incident and subsequent scrutiny have damaged Boeing's reputation. Boeing Chairman Steven Mollenkopf said Ortberg was chosen after a \"thorough and extensive search process\"\u009d and \"has the right skills and experience to lead Boeing in its next chapter.\"\u009d Ortberg has earned a reputation for running complex engineering and manufacturing companies, Mollenkopf said. The company waived the mandatory retirement age of 65 for Ortberg, a spokesperson said. Boeing did the same for Calhoun days after he turned 64 in 2021. Ortberg emerged as a leading candidate only recently. Others who were reportedly considered for the job included Patrick Shanahan, a former Boeing executive and now CEO of its most important supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, and another longtime Boeing executive, Stephanie Pope, who recently took over the commercial airplanes division. Ortberg led Rockwell Collins from 2013 to 2018, when it merged with United Technologies and wound up as part of RTX, the company formerly known as Raytheon. He retired from RTX in 2021. Richard Aboulafia, a longtime aerospace analyst and consultant and recently a harsh critic of the company, said the hire is great news for Boeing. \"He is a deeply respected leader in the aerospace industry, and brings more hope for a better future than the company has enjoyed in decades,\"\u009d Aboulafia said. Deutsche Bank analyst Scott Deuschle said Ortberg \"has an engineering background, experience in the aviation industry, and experience as a public company CEO.\"\u009d In a statement issued by Boeing, Ortberg said, \"There is much work to be done, and I'm looking forward to getting started.\" Calhoun will serve as a special adviser to the Boeing board until next March. Like Calhoun, who took over as CEO in the wake of the two Max crashes, Ortberg inherits the leadership of a company facing ongoing crises and criticism from inside and outside the company. Boeing, based in Arlington, Virginia, is pushing back against whistleblower allegations of manufacturing shortcuts that crimp on safety. It is dealing with supply-chain problems that are hindering production, which it hopes to fix in part by re-acquiring Spirit AeroSystems, a key contractor. It faces a threatened strike this fall by its largest union, the International Association of Machinists. The company is still trying to persuade regulators to approve two new models of the Max and a bigger version of its two-aisle 777 jetliner. And it faces a multi-billion-dollar decision on when to design a new single-aisle plane to replace the Max. The quarterly earnings reported Wednesday reflected the continuing challenges at Boeing. The reported loss of $1.44 billion for the second quarter compared with a loss of $149 million a year earlier. Since the start of 2019, Boeing has lost more than $25 billion. Excluding special items, the second-quarter loss worked out to $2.90 per share. Analysts expected a loss of $1.90 per share, according to a FactSet survey. Revenue dropped 15%, to $16.87 billion, falling short of Wall Street's average forecast of $17.35 billion. The commercial airplanes division had an operating loss of $715 million, and revenue plunged 32% as Boeing delivered fewer passenger jets to airlines - 92 planes, compared with 136 a year earlier. The FAA limited Boeing's production of Max jetliners shortly after the Alaska Airlines incident, but Boeing hasn't even hit the FAA limits as it seeks to fix its manufacturing process. The company said Wednesday that it is sticking with its plans to boost production of the Max to 38 per month by year end. Boeing took a charge of $244 million to cover a fine it agreed to pay as part of its plea deal with the Justice Department in connection with development of the Max. A federal judge in Texas will soon consider whether to approve the agreement, which also calls for the appointment of an independent compliance monitor and for Boeing to invest at least $455 million \"in its compliance, quality, and safety programs.\"\u009d Many families of the people who died in the two Max crashes, which took place off the coast of Indonesia in 2018 and in Ethiopia less than five months later, oppose the deal and plan to ask the judge to reject it. Boeing's defense and space unit lost $913 million because of $1 billion in setbacks to four fixed-price government contracts, including a deal to build two new Air Force One presidential jets. The smaller services business earned $870 million. Boeing shares rose 2% in morning trading.", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medicine Hat News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "canadian_press@medicinehatnews.com",
